editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed for Humphrey Robinson ... and for Humphrey Moseley ...,

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

projectDesc.p: This is a very early release with many imperfections. Contact martinmueller@northwestern.edu for corrections and improvement. For more information about the project go to http://scalablereading.northwestern.edu

editorialDecl.p: These texts have been encoded in TEI Simple, but retain all the structural distinctions found in the TCP texts fron which they were derived. The facs attributes for each pb; and welement provide a link to the EEBO pages images. A list of the NUPOS2 tags with descriptiosn and examples can be found at href="http://morphadorner.northwestern.edu/morphadorner/schemata/nupos2-interpgrp.xml"

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter sir perfidious Old-craft an old knight, and Witty-pate his son.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Sir I'm no boy, I'm deep in one and twenty,
The second year's approaching.

sp.speaker: Old K.
sp.l: A fine time
For a youth to live by his wits then I should think,
If e'er he mean to make account of any.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Wit's sir?

sp.speaker: Old K.
sp.l: I wit's sir, if it be so strange to thee,
I'm sorry I spent that time to get a fool,
I might have employed my pains a great deal better;
Thou knowest all that I have I ha got by my wits,
And yet to see how urgent thou art too;
It grieves me thou art so degenerate
To trouble me for means, I never offered it:
My parents from a schoolboy, passed nineteen once,
See what these times are grown too, before twenty
I rushed into the world, which is indeed
Much like the art of swimming, he that will attain to't
Must fall plump, and duck himself at first,
And that will make him hardy and adventurous,
And not stand putting in one foot and shiver,
And then draw tother after, like a quake-buttock;
Well he may make a paddler i' the world,
From hand to mouth, but never a brave swimmer,
Born up by th' chin as I bore up myself ▪
With my strong industry that never failed me;
For he that lies born up with patrimonies,
Looks like a long great ass that swims with bladders,
Come but one prick of adverse fortune to him
He sinks, because he never tried to swim
When wit plays with the billows that choked him.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Why is it not a fashion for a father sir,
Out of his yearly thousands, to allow
His only son a competent brace of hundreds,
Or such a toy?

sp.speaker: Old K.
sp.l: Yes, if he mean to spoil him,
Or mar his wits he may, but never I
This is my humour sir, which you'll find constant;
I love wit so well because I lived by't,
That I'll give no man power out of my means to hurt it,
And that's a kind of gratitude to my raiser,
Which great ones oft forget; I admire much
This age's dulness, when I scarce writ man,
The first degree that e'er I took in thriving,
I lay intelligencer close for wenching,
Could give this lord or knight a true certificate
Of all the maidenheads extant, how many lay
'Mongst chambermaids, how many'mongst exchange wenches,
Though never many there I must confess,
They have a trick to utter ware so fast;
I knew which lady had a mind to fall,
Which gentlewoman new divorced, which tradesman breaking,
The price of every sinner to a hair,
And where to raise each price; which were the termers
That would give velvet petticoats, tissue gowns,
Which pieces, angels, suppers, and half crowns;
I knew how to match and make my market,
Could give intelligence where the pox lay ledger,
And then to see the lechers shift a point,
'Twas sport and profit too; how they would shun
Their adored mistress chambers, and run fearfully,
Like rats from burning houses, so brought I
My clients a the game still safe together,
And noble gamesters loved me, and I felt it:
Give me a man that lives by his wits say I,
And never left a groat, there's the true gallant.
When I grew somewhat pursy, I grew then
In men's opinions too, and confidences,
They put things called executorships upon me,
The charge of orphans, little senseless creatures,
Whom in their childe-hoods I bound forth to feltmakers,
To make 'em lose and work away their gentry,
Disguise their tender natures with hard custom,
So wrought 'em out in time, there I rise ungently,
Nor do I fear to discourse this unto thee,
I'm armed at all points against treachery,
I hold my humour firm, if I can see thee thrive by
Thy wits while I live, I shall have the more courage
To trust thee with my lands when I die; if not,
The next best wit I can hear of carries 'em:
For since in my time and knowledge so many rich children
Of the city conclude in beggary, I'd rather
Make a wise stranger my executor, than a foolish
Son my heir, and to have my lands called after my
Wit, thou after my name; and that's my nature.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: 'Tis a strange harsh one, must I still shift then?
I come brave cheats, once to my trade again,
And I'll ply't harder now than e'er I did for't,
You'll part with nothing then, sir?

sp.speaker: Old K.
sp.l: Not a jot sir.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: If I should ask you blessing ere I go sir,
I think you would not give't me.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Let me but hear thou livest by thy wits once
Thou shalt have any thing, thou'rt none of mine else,
Then why should I take care for thee?

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: 'Thank your bounty.Exit

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: So wealth love me, and long life, I beseech it,
As I do love the man that lives by his wits,
He comes so near my nature; I'm grown old now,
And e'en arrived at my last cheat I fear me,
But 'twill make shift to bury me, by daylight too,
And discharge all my legacies, 'tis so wealthy,
And never trouble any interest money:
I've yet a niece to wed, over whose steps
I have placest a trusty watchful guardiness,
For fear some poor Earl steal her, 't has been threatened
To redeem mortgaged land, but he shall miss on't;
To prevent which, I have sought out a match for her,
Fop of Fop-hall, he writes himself, I take it,
The ancientantient'st fop in England, with whom I'm privately
Compounded for the third part of her portion,
sp.stage: Enter sir Gregory fop, and Cuningham.
sp.l: And she seems pleased, so two parts rest with me,
He's come; sir Gregory, welcome, what's he sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Young Cunningham, a Norfolk gentleman,
One that has lived upon the fops, my kindred,
Ever since my remembrance; he's a wit indeed,
And we all strive to have him, nay, 'tis certain
Some of our name has gone to law for him;
Now 'tis my turn to keep him, and indeed
He's plaguy chargeable as all your wit, are,
But I will give him over when I list,
I ha' used wits so before.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Hope when you're married sir you'll shake him off.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Why what do you take me to be, old father in-law that shall be, do you think I'll have any of the wits hang upon nigh after I am married once? none of my kindred ever had before me; but where's this niece? is't a fashion in London to marry a woman and never see her?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Excuse the niceness sir, that cares your friend,
Perhaps had she been seen, you had never seen her;
There's many a spent-thing called an't like your honour,
That lies in wait for her at first snap, she's a countess,
Drawn with six mares through Fleetstreet, and a coachman,
Sitting bareheaded to their Flanders buttocks,
This whets him on.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Pray let's clap up the business sir,
I long to see her, are you sure you have her,
Is she not there already? Hark, oh hark.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: How now, what's that sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Every caroche goes by,
Goes e'en toth' heart of me.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: I'll have that doubt eased sir,
Instantly cased, sir Gregory, and now I think on't
A toy comes i' my mind, seeing your friend there,
We'll have a little sport, give you but way to't,
And put a trick upon her, I love wit preciously,
You shall not be seen yet, we'll stale your friend first,
If't please but him to stand for the antimask.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Puh, he shall stand for any thing, why his supper
Lies i' my breeches here, I'll make him fast else.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Then come you forth more unexpectedly
The mask itself, a thousand a year jointure,
The cloud your friend will be then drawn away,
And only you the beauty of the play.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: For red and black I'll put down all your Fuller
Let but your niece bring white, and we have three cullours. Exit sir greg.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: I'm given to understand you are a wit sir.

sp.speaker: Cunning.
sp.l: I'm one that fortune shows small favour to sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Why there you conclude it, whether you will or no sir;
To tell you truth, I'm taken with a wit.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Fowlers catch woodcocks so, let not them know so much,

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: A pestilence mazzard, a Duke Humphrey spark
Had rather lose his dinner than his jest,
I say, I love a wit the best of all things.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Always except yourself.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Has gin't me twice now,
All with a breath, I thank him; but that I love a wit
I should be heartily angry; cuds, my niece,
You know the business with her,

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: With a woman?
'Tis e'en the very same it was I'm sure
Five thousand years ago , no fool can miss it.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: This is the gentleman I promised niece,
To present to your affection.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: 'Ware that arrow.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Deliver me the truth now of your liking.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I'm spoiled already, that such poor lean game
Should be found out as I am.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Go set too her sir — ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: How noble is this virtue in you lady,
Your eye may seem to commit thousand slaughters
On your dull servants, which truly tasted
Conclude all in comforts.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Puh.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: It rather shows what a truth worth can make,
Such as yours is.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: And that's not worth a groat,
How like you him niece?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: It shall appear how well sir,
I humbly thank you for him.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Ha? ha, good gullory, he does it well i'faith,
Light, as if he meant to purchase lip-land there:
Hold, hold, bear off I say, slid your part hangs too long.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: My joys are mockeries.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: You've both expressed a worthy care and love sir,
Had mine own eye been set at liberty,
To make a public choice (Believe my truth sir)
It could not ha' done better for my heart
Then your good providence has.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: You will say so then,
Alas sweet niece, all this is but the scabbard,
Now I draw forth the weapon.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Sir Gregory,
Approach thou lad of thousands.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Who calls me?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: What motion's this? the model of Niniveh?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Accost her daintily now, let me advise thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I was advised to bestow dainty cost on you.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: You were ill advised, back, and take better counsel;
You may have good for an angel, the least cost
You can bestow upon a woman sir
Trebles ten counsellors fees, in lady-ware,
You're over head and ears ere you be aware,
Faith keep a bachelor still, and go to bowls sir,
Follow your mistress there, and prick and save sir,
For other mistresses will make you a slave sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: So, so, I have ray lirripoop already.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Why how now niece, this is the man I tell you.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: He, hang him sir, I know you do but mock,
This is the man you would say.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: The devil rides I think.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I must use cunning here.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Make me not mad, use him with all respect,
This is the man I swear.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Would you could persuade me to that;
Alas, you cannot go beyond me uncle.
You carry a lest well I must confess,
For a man of your years, but —

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: I'm wrought beside myself.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I never beheld comeliness till this minute.

sp.speaker: Guar.
sp.l: O good sweet sir, pray offer not these wards
To an old gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Away fifteen,
Here's fifty one exceeds thee.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: What's the business?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Give me these motherly creatures, come, never smother it,
I know you are a teeming woman yet.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: Troth a young gent. might do much I think sir

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Go too then.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: And I should play my part, or I were ingrateful.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Can you so soon neglect me?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Hence, I'm busy.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: This cross point came in luckily, impudent baggage.
Hang from the gentleman, art thou not ashamed
To be a widow's hindrance?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Are you angry sir?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: You're welcome, pray court on, I shall desire
Your honest wise acquaintance; vex me not
After my care and pains to find a match for thee,
Lest I confine thy life to some out chamber,
Where thou shalt waste the sweetness of thy youth,
Like a consuming light in her own socket,
And not allowed a male creature about thee;
A very monkey thy necessity
Shall prize at a thousand pound a chimney-sweeper
At fifteen hundred.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: But are you serious uncle?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Serious.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Pray let me look upon the gentleman
With more heed, than I did but hum him over
In haste, good faith, as lawyer's chancery sheets;
Beshrew my blood a tolerable man,
Now I distinctly read him.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Hum, hum, hum.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Say he be black, he's of a very good pitch,
Well ankled, two good confident calves, they look
As if they would not shrink at the ninth child;
The redness ith' face, why that's in fashion,
Most of your high bloods have it, sign of greatness marry;
'Tis to be taken down too with may butter,
I'll send to my lady Spend-tail for her medicine.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Lum te dum, dum, dum, de dum.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: He's qualified too, believe me.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Lum to dumb, de dum, de dum.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Where was my judgement?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Lum te dum, dum, dum, te dum, te dum.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Perfections covered mess.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Lum te dum, te dum, te dum.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: It smokes apparently, pardon sweet sir
The error of my sex.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Why well said niece,
Upon submission you must pardon her now sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I'll do't by course, do you think I'm an ass knight?
Here's first my hand, now't goes to the seal office.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Formally finished, how goes this suit forward?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I'm taking measure of the widow's mind sir,
I hope to fit her heart.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: Who would have dreamt
Of a young morsel now? things come in minutes.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Trust him not widow, he's a younger brother,
He'll swear and lie; believe more he's worth nothing.

sp.speaker: Guard.
sp.l: He brings more content to a woman with that nothing,
Than he that brings his thousands without any thing,
We have presidents for that amongst great ladies.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Come, come, no language now shall be in fashion,
But your love-phrase the bell to procreation. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter sir ruinous gentry, Witty-pate, and Priscian.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Pax, there's nothing puts me besides my wits, but this fourth,
This lay illiterate share, there's no conscience in 't.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.l: Sir, it has ever been so where I have practised, and must be
Sill where I am, nor has it been undeserved at the years
End, and shuffle the almanac together, vacations and
Term-times one with another, though I say't, my wife is a
Woman of a good spirit, than it is no lay-share.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: Faith for this five year, ego possum probare, I have had
A hungry penurious share with 'em, and she has had as much
As I always.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Present or not present?

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: Residens aut non residens, perfidem.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: And what president's this for me? because your hic et hac, turpis and qui mihi discipulus brains (That never got any thing but by accidence and uncertainty) did allow it, therefore I must, that have grounded conclusions of wit, hereditary rules for my father to get by.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.p: Sir be compendious, either take or refuse, I will bate no token of my wife's share, make even the last reckonings, and either so unite or here divide company.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: A good resolution, profecto, let every man beg his own way, and happy man be his dole.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Well, here's your double share, and single brains Pol, edipo, here's towards, a caster ecastor for you, I will endure it a fortnight longer, but by these just five ends —

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Take heed, Five's odd, put both hands together or severally they are all odd unjust ends.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p:
Medeius sidius, hold your tongue, I depose you from half a share presently else, I will make you a participle and decline you, now you understand me, be you a quiet conjunction amongst the undeclined; you and your Latin ends shall go shift, solus cum solo together else, and then if ever they got ends of gold and silver enough to
serve that gerundine maw of yours, that without do will end in di et dum instantly.

div.stage: Enter old knight and sir Gregory.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.p: Enough, enough, here comes company, we lose five shares in wrangling about one.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: My father, put on Priscian, he has Latin fragments too, but I fear him not, I'll case my face with a little more hair and relieve.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Tush nephew (I'll call you so) for if there be
No other obstacles then those you speak of
They are but powder charges without pellets,
You may safely front 'em; and warrant your own danger.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: No other that I can perceive i'faith sir, for I put her to't, and felt her as far as I could, and the strongest repulse was, she said, she would have a little soldier in me, that (If need were) I should defend her reputation.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: And surely sir, that is a principle
Amongst your principal ladies, they require
Valour either in a friend or a husband.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: And I allow their requests i'faith, as well as any woman's heart can desire, if I knew where to get valour, I would as willingly entertain it as any man that blows.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: Breathes, breathes sir, that's the sweeter phrase.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Blows for a soldier, i'faith sir, and I'm in
Practice that way.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: For a soldier, I grant it.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Slid I'll swallow some bullets, and good round ones too, but I'll have a little soldier in me.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.p: Will you on and beg, or steal and be hanged.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: And some scholar she would have me besides,
Tush, that shall be no bar, 'tis a quality in a
Gentleman, but of the least question.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Salvete domini benignissimi, munificentissimi.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Salvete dicis ad nos? fubeo te salvere,
Nay sir, we have Latin and other mettle in us too,
Sir, you shall see talk with this fellow now.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I could find in my heart to talk with him too,
If I could understand him.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: Charissimi, doctissimiq. Domini, ex abundantia,
Charitatis vestrae estote poopitii in me junenem,
Miserum, pauperem, et omni consolation exulem.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: A pretty scholar by my faith sir, but I'll to him again.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Does he beg or steal in this language can you tell sir?
He may take away my good name from me, and I never
The wiser.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: He begs, he begs sir.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: Ecce, ecce, in oculis lacrymarum flumen, in ore
Fames, sitisq. ignis in vultu, pudor et impudentia,
In omni parte necessitas et indigentia.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Audi tu bonus socius, tu es scolasticus, sic intelligo,
Ego faciam argumentum, mark now sir, now I fetch
Him up.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I have been fetched up a hundred times for this,
Yet I could never learn half so much.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Audi, and respond, hoc est argumentum, nomen est
Nomen, ergo, quod est tibi nomen, respond nunc,
Respond argumentum meum. Have I not put him to't sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Yes sir, I think so.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Step in, the rascal is put out of his penned speech,
And he can go no farther.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: Cur non responds?

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: O dominae, tanta mea est miseria.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: So he's almost in again.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: Ut nocte mecum pernoctat egestas, luce quotidie
Paupertat habitat.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Said quid est tibi nomen, et quis dedit? Respond
Argumentum.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Hem, hem.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: He's dry, he hems, on quickly.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.p: Courteous gentlemen, if the brow of a military face may not be offensive to your generous eyeballs, let his wounds speak better than his words, for some branch or small sprig of charity to be planted upon this poor barren soil of a soldier.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: How now, what arms and arts both go a-begging ?

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.p: Such is the post-progress of cold charity nowadays , who (For heat to her frigid limbs) passes in so swift a motion, that two at the least had need be to stay her.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Sir, let's reward 'em I pray you and be gone, if any quarrel should arise amongst us, I am able to answer neither of them, his iron and steel tongue is as hard as the tother's Latin one.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Stay, stay sir, I will talk a little with him first,
Let me alone with both, I will try whether they
Live by their wits or no; for such a man I love,
And what? you both beg together then?

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: Conjunctis manibus, profecto, dominae.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.p: With equal fortunes equal distribution, there's not the breadth of a sword's point uneven in our division.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: What two qualities are here cast away upon two poor fellows, if a man had 'em that could maintain 'em, what a double man were that, if these two fellows might be bought and sodden, and boiled to a jelly, and eaten fasting every morning, I do not think but a man should find strange things in his stomach.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: Come sir, join your charity with mine, and we'll make up a couple of pence betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: If a man could have a pennyworth for his penny, I would bestow more money with 'em.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Save you gentlemen, how now? what are you encountered here? what fellows are these?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: I'faith sir, here's Mars and Mercury, a pair of poor planets it seems, that Jupiter has turned out to live by their wits, and we are e'en about a little spark of charity to kindle 'em a new fire.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Stay, pray you stay sir, you may abuse your charity, nay make that goodness in you no better than a vice, so many deceivers walk in these shadows nowadays , that certainly your bounties were better spilt than reserved to so lewd and vicious uses; which is he that professes the soldier?

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.p: He that professes his own profession sir, and the dangerous life he hath led in it this pair of half score years.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: In what services have you been sir?

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.p: The first that fleshed me a soldier sir, was that great battle at Aleazar in Barbary, where the noble English Stukely fell, and where that royal Portugal Sebastian ended his untimely days.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Are you sure Sebastian died there?

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.p: Faith sir, there was some other rumour hoped amongst us, that he wounded escaped, and touched on his native shore again, where finding his country at home more distressed by the invasion of the Spaniard then his loss abroad, forsook it, still supporting a miserable and unfortunate life, which (Where he ended) is yet uncertain.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: By my faith sir, he speaks the nearest same of truth in this.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.p: Since sir, I served in France, the low countries, lastly, at that memorable skirmish at Newport, where the forward and bold scot there spent his life so freely, that from every single heart that there fell, came home from his resolution a double honour to his country.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: This should be no counterfeit, sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: I do not think he is, sir.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: But sir, methinks you do not show the marks of a soldier, could you so freely scape, that you brought home no scars to be your chronicle?

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.p: Sir, I have wounds and many, but in those parts where nature and humanity bids me shame to publish.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: A good soldier cannot want those badges.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Now am not I of your mind in that, for I hold him the best soldier that scapes best, always at a cock-fencing I give him the best that has the fewest knocks.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Nay I'll have a bout with your scholar too,
To ask you why you should be poor (Yet richly learned)
Were no question, at least you can easily
Answer it; but whether you have learning enough,
To deserve to be poor or no (Since poverty is
Commonly the meed of learning) is yet to be tried;
You have the languages, I mean the chief,
As the hebrew, Syriack, greek, Latin, etc.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Aliquantulum, non totaliter, dominae.

sp.speaker: O.k.
sp.l: The Latin I have sufficiently tried him in,
And I promise you sir he is very well grounded.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: I will prove him in some of the rest.
Tois miois fatherois iste cockscomb boy?

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Kay yonkeron niggitton oy fouleroi asinisoy.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Cheateron ton biton?

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Tous pollous strikerous, Angelo to peeso.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Certainly sir, a very excellent scholar in the Greek.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: I do note a wondrous readiness in him.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I do wonder how the Trojans could hold out ten years siege (As 'tis reported) against the Greeks, if Achilles spoke but this tongue? I do not think but he might have shaken down the walls in a seventh-night, and never troubled the wooden horse.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: I will try him so far as I can in the Syriack.
Kircom bragmen, shag a dou ma dell mathou.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Hashagath rabgabash shobos onoriadka.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Colpack Rubasca, gnawerthem shigshag.
Napshamothem ribsbe bongomosh lashemech nagothi.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Gentlemen I have done, any man that can, go further,
I confess myself at a nonplus.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Faith not I sir, I was at my farthest in my natural language, I was never double-tongued I thank my hard fortune.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Well gentlemen, 'tis pity (Walk further off a little my friends) I say, 'tis pity such fellows so endowed, so qualified with the gifts of nature and arts, yet should have such a scarcity of fortunes benefits, we must blame our iron-hearted age for it.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: 'Tis pity indeed, and our pity shall speak a little for 'em;
Come sir, here's my groat.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: A groat sir? o fie, give nothing rather, 'twere better you railed on 'em for begging and so quit yourself, I am a poor gentleman, that have little but my wits to live on.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: Troth and I love you the better, sir.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Yet I'll begin a better example than so, here fellows, there's between you, take purse and all, and I would it were heavier for your sakes, there's a pair of angels to guide you to your lodgings, a poor gentleman's good will.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Gratias, maximas gratias, benignissime dominae.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: This is an ill example for us, sir, I would this bountiful gentleman had not come this way today.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Pox, we must not shame ourselves now, sir, I'll give as much as that gentleman, though I never be soldier or scholar while I live; here friends, there's a piece, that if he were divided would make a pair of angels for me too, in the love I bear to the sword and the tongues.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: My largesse shall be equal too, and much good do you, this bounty is a little abatement of my wit though, I feel that.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.p: May soldiers ever defend such charities.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: And scholars pray for their increase.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: Fare you well sir, these fellows may pray for you, you have made the scholar's commons exceed today, and a word with you, sir, you said you lived by your wits, if you use this bounty you'll beggar your wits believe it.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: O sir, I hope to increase 'em by it, this seed never wants his harvest, fare you well, sir.Exit

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I think a man were as good mere with a reasonable thief, as an unreasonable beggar sometimes, I could find in my heart to beg half mine back again, can you change my piece my friends?

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Tempora mutantur, et nos mutamur in illis.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: My gold is turned into Latin,
Look you good fellows, here's one round
Shilling more that lay concealed.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: Sir, away, we shall be drawn farther into damage else.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: A pox of the fool, he live by his wits? if his wits leave him any money but what he begs or steals very shortly, I'll be hanged for him.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.p: This breakfast parcel was well fetched of i'faith.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Tush, a byblow for mirth, we must have better purchase, we want a fourth for another project that I have ripened.

sp.speaker: Ruin,
sp.p: My wife, she shares, and can deserve it.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: She can change her shape, and be masculine.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.p: 'Tis one of the freest conditions, she fears not the crack of a pistol, she dares say stand to a grazier.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Probatum fuit, profecto, dominae.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Good, than you sir Bacchus, Apollo shall be dispatched with her share, and some contents to meet us tomorrow (At a certain place and time appointed) in the masculine gender, my father has a nephew, and I an own cousin coming up from the university, whom he loves most indulgently, easy master credulous oldcraft, (For you know what your mere academic is) your carrier never misses his hour, he must not be robbed (Because he has but little to lose) but he must join with us in a device that I have, that shall rob my father of a hundred pieces, and thank me to be rid on't, for there's the ambition of my wit to live upon his professed wit, that has turned me out to live by my wits.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Cum hirundinis alis tibi regratulor.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: A male habit, a bag of a hundred weight, though it be counters (For my alchemy shall turn 'em into gold of my fathers) the hour, the place, the action shall be at large set down, and father, you shall know, that I put my portion to use, that have given me to live by;
And to confirm yourself in me renate,
I hope you'll find my wits legitimate. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Nay lady.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Put me not in mind on't prithee,
You cannot do a greater wrong to women,
For in our wants, 'tis the most chief affliction
To have that name remembered; 'tis a title
That misery works us by, and the world's malice,
Scorn and contempt has not where with to work
On humble callings; they are safe, and lie
Level with pity still, and pale distress
Is no great stranger to 'em; but when fortune
Looks with a stormy face on our conditions,
We find affliction work, and envy pastime,
And our worst enemy then that most abuses us,
Is that we are called by, lady, oh my spirit,
Will nothing make thee humble? I am well methinks,
And can live quiet with my fate sometimes,
Until I look into the world again,
Then I begin to rave at my stars bitterness,
To see how many muck hills placed above me;
Peasants and droils, caroches full of dunghills,
Whose very birth stinks in a generous nostril,
Glistering by night like glowworms through the high-streets,
Hurried by torchlight in the footman's hands
That show like running fire-drakes through the city,
And I put to my shifts and wits to live,
Nay sometimes danger too; on foot, on horseback,
And earn my supper manfully ere I get it,
Many a meal I have purchased at that rate,
Fed with a wound upon me, stamped at midnight.
Ha, what are you?

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: Now you may tell yourself lady. Pulls off's beard

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: O Mr. Priscian, what's the project,
For you never come without one.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: First, your husband,
Sir ruinous gentry greets you with best wishes,
And here has sent you your full share by me
In five cheats, and two robberies.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: And what comes it too?

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: Near upon thirteen pound.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: A goodly share.
'Twill put a, lady scarce in Philip and Cheyney,
With three small bugle laces, like a chambermaid,
Here's precious living.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: Alas you must consider, lady,
'Tis but young term, attorneys ha' small doings yet,
Then highway lawyers, they must needs ha little,
We've had no great good luck to speak troth beauty,
Since your stout ladyship parted from is at Highgate,
But there's a fair hope now for a present hundred,
Here's man's apparel, your horse stands at door.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: And what's the virtuous plot now?

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: Marry lady,
You like a brave young gallant must be robbed.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I robbed?

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: Nay then —

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Well, well, go on, let's hear sir.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: Here's a sealed bag of a hundred, which indeed
Are counters all, only some sixteen groats
Of white money i'the mouth on't.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: So, what saddle have I?

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: Monsieur Laroon's the Frenchman's.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: That again,
You know so well it is not for my stride,
How oft have I complained on't?

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: You nay have jockeys then, the little Scotch one,
You must dispatch. Exit Pris.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: I'll soon by ready sir,
Before you ha' shifted saddles, many women
Have their wealth flow to 'em, I was made I see
To help my fortune, not my fortune me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: My ways are goblin-led, and the night else
Still draw me from my home, yet I follow,
Sure 'tis not altogether fabulous,
Such hags do get dominion of our tongues
So soon as we speak, the enchantment binds;
I have dissembled such a trouble on me,
As my best wits can hardly clear again;
Piping through this old reed, the guardianess,
With purpose that my harmony shall reach
And please the lady's ear, she stops below,
And echoes back my love unto my lips,
Persuaded by most violent arguments
Of self-love in herself; I am so self-fool,
To do at upon her hundred-wrinkled face;
I could beggar her to accept the gifts
She would throw upon me; 'twere charity,
But for pities sake I will be a niggard
And undo, her, refusing to take from her;
I'm haunted again, if it take not now
I'll break the spell.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Sweet Cuningame, welcome;
What? A whole day absent? Birds that build nests
Have care to keep 'em.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: That's granted,
But not continually to sit upon 'em;
Less in the youngling season, else they desire
To fly abroad, and recreate their labours,
Than they return with fresher appetite
To work again.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Well, well, you have built a nest
That will stand all storms, you need not mistrust
A weather-wrack, and one day it may be
The youngling season too, than I hope
You'll never fly out of sight.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: There will be pains,
I see to shake this burr off, and sweetest,
Prithee how fares thy charge? has my good friend
Sir Gregory the countenance of a lover?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: No by my troth, not in my mind, methinks
(Setting his worship aside) he looks like a fool.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Nay i'faith, never divide his worship from him for that
Small matter; fool and worship are no such
Strangers now adays, but my meaning is,
Has he thy lady's countenance of love?
Looks she like a welcome on him? plainly,
Have they as good hope of one another,
As Cupid bless us, we have?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Troth I know not,
I can perceive no forwardness in my charge,
But I protest I wish the knight better
For your sake, bird.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Why thanks sweet bird, and with my heart I wish,
That he had as strong and likely hope of her
As thou haste of me.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Well, he's like to speed
Never the worse for that good wish, and I'll tell you
Bird (For secrets are not to be kept betwixt us two)
My charge thinks well of you.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Of me? for what?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: For my sake, I mean so, I have heard her
A hundred times since her. Uncle gave her
The first bob about you, that she'd do somewhat
For my sake if things went well together,
We have spoke of doors and bolts, and things and things,
Go too, I'll tell you all, but you'll find
Some advancement for my sake I do believe.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Faith be not sparing, tell me.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: By my lady
You shall pardon me for that, 'twere a shame
If men should hear all that women speaks behind
Their backs sometimes.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: You must give me leave yet,
At least to give her thanks.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Not that neither,
She must not take a notice of my blabbing,
It is sufficient you shall give me thanks,
For 'tis for my sake if she be bountiful,
She loves me, and loves you too for my sake.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: How shall I knowing this but be ingrate,
Not to repay her with my dearest duty.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Ay, but you must not know it, if you tell
All that I open to you, you'll shame us both;
Afar off you may kiss your hand, blush, or so,
But I'll allow no nearer conference.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Whoop! you'll be jealous I perceive now.

sp.speaker: Gad.
sp.l: Jealous? why there's no true love without it, bird,
I must be jealous of thee, but for her,
(Were it within my duty to my master)
I durst trust her with the strongest tempter,
And I dare swear her now as pure a virgin
As e'er was welcomed to a marriage bed,
If thoughts may be untainted, hers are so.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: And where's the cause of your fear then?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Well, well;
When things are past, and the wedding torches
Lighted at matches, to kindle better fire,
Then I'll tell you more.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Come, come, I see further,
That if we were married you'd be jealous.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: I protest I should a little, but not of her,
It is the married woman (If you mark it)
And not the maid that longs, the appetite
Follows the first taste, when we have relished
We wish cloying, the taste once pleased before,
Than our desire is whetted on to more,
But I reveal too much to you, i'faith bird.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Not a whit i'faith, bird, betwixt you and I,
I am beholding for bettering of my knowledge.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Nay you shall know more of me if you'll be ruled,
But make not things common.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Ud'so, your lady?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Ay, 'tis no matter, she'll like well of this,
Our familiarity is her content.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: This present from sir Gregory?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: From my master, the worshipful right sir Gregory fop

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: A ruff? and what might be his high conceit
In sending of a ruff?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I think he had two conceits in it forsooth, too high too
Low, ruff high, because as the ruff does embrace your
Neck all day, so does he desire to throw his knightly arms.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: But then I leave him off a nights.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Why then he is ruff low, a ruffian, a bold adventurous errant to do any rough service for his lady.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: A witty and unhappy conceit, does he mean
As he seems to say unto that reverence?Towards
He does woo her sure. Cuning.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: To tell you truth lady, his conceit was far better than I have blazed it yet.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Do you think so, sir?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Nay I know it forsooth, for it was two days ere he compassed it, to find a fitting present for your ladyship, was sending once a very fine puppy to you.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: And that he would have brought himself.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: So he would indeed, but then he altered his device, and sent this ruff, requesting withal, that whensoever it is foul, you (With your own hands) would bestow the starching of it.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.p: Else she woos him, now his eyes shoots this way; and what was the reason for that sir?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: There lies his main conceit, lady, for says he, in so doing she cannot choose but in the starching to clap it often between her hands, and so she gives a great liking and applause to my present, whereas if I should send a puppy; she ever calls it to her with irist, hiss, hiss, which is a fearful disgrace, he drew the devil from a play, at the bull tother day.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: I marry sir, this was a rich conceit indeed.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: And far fetched, therefore good for you lady -

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: How now? which way look you, bird?

sp.speaker: Can.
sp.l: At the fool bird shall I hot look at the fool?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: At the fool and I here? what need that? pray look this way.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: I'll fit him aptly, either I'll awake
His wits (If he have any) or force him
To appear (As yet I cannot think him)
Without any, sirrah, tell me one thing true
That I shall ask you now, was this device
Your masters own? I doubt his wit in it;
He's not so ingenious.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: His own I assure you, madam.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Nay, you must not lie.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Not with a lady, I'd rather lie with you then lie with my master, by your leave in such a case as this.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Yet again your eye?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: The fool makes mirth i'faith,
I would hear some.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Come, you shall hear none but me.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Come hither friend, nay come near me; did
Thy master send thee to me? he may be wise,
But did not she it much in that; men sometimes
May wrong themselves unawares, when they least think on 't;
Was Vulcan ever so unwise, to send Mars
To be his spokesman when he went a-wooing ?
Send thee? heigh-ho, a pretty rolling eye.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I can turn up the white and the black too, and need be, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Why, here's an amorous nose.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: You see the worst of my nose, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: A cheek, how I could put it now in dalliance,
A pair of lips, o that we were honeyed,
I could suck sugar from 'em, what a beard's here?
When will the knight thy master have such a
Stamp of manhood on his face? nay, do not blush.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: 'Tis nothing but my flesh and blood that rises so.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Death, she courts the fool.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Away, away, 'tis sport, do not mind it.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Give me thy hand, come be familiar;
Ay, here's a promising palm; what a soft
Handful of pleasure's here, here's down compared
With flocks and quilted straw, thy knights fingers
Are lean mattress rubbers to these feathers,
I prithee let me lean my cheek upon't,
What a soft pillow's here?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Hum, umh, hu, hum.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Why there's a courage in that lively passion,
Measure thee all o'er, there's not a limb
But has his full proportion; it is my voice,
There's no compare betwixt the knight and thee,
The goodlier man by half, at once now
I see thee all over.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: If you had seen me swim tother day on my back, you would have said you had seen, there was two chambermaids that saw me, and my legs by chance were tangled in the flags, and when they saw how I was hanged, they cried out, oh help the man for fear he be drowned.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.p: They could do no less in pity, come, thine arm, we'll walk together.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Blindness of love and women, why she dotes upon the fool.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: What's that to you, mind her not.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Away you burr.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: How's that?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Hang of fleshook, fasten thine itchy clasp
On some dry toadstool that will kindle with thee,
And burn together.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: O abominable,
Why do you not love me?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: No, never did?
I took thee down a little way to
Enforce a vomit from my offended stomach,
Now thou'rt up again I loathe thee filthily.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: O villain.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Why dost thou not see a sight
Would make a man abjure the sight of women.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, he's vexed; ha, ha, ha,
Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Why dost thou laugh?
Because thou laughest, nothing else i'faith.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: She has but mocked my folly, else she finds not
The bosom of my purpose, some other way
Must make me know; I'll try her, and may chance quit
The fine dexterity of her lady-wit. Exit.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Yes introth, I laughed to think of thy master,
Now, what he would think if he knew this?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: By my troth I laugh at him too, faith sirrah, he's but a fool to say the truth, though I say't that should not say't.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Yes, thou shouldst say truth, and I believe thee;
Well, for this time we'll part, you perceive something,
Our tongues betray our hearts, there's our weakness,
But pray be silent.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: As mouse in cheese, or goose in hay i'faith.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.p: Look, we are cut off, there's my hand where my lips would be.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I'll wink and think 'em thy lips, farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Now gardionesse, I need not ask where you have been.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: O lady, never was woman so abused

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Dost thou hear lady sweetheart, I had forgotten to tell thee, if you will I will come back in the evening?

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: By no means, come not till I send for you.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: If there be any need, you may think of things when I am gone, I may be conveyed into your chamber, I'll lie under the bed while midnight, or so, or you shall put me up in one of your little boxes, I can creep in at a small hole.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.p: These are things I dare not venture, I charge you on my love never come till I send for you.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Verbum insapienti, 'tis enough to the wise, nor I think it is not fit the knight should know any thing yet.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: By no means, pray you go now, we are suspected.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: For the things that are past, let us use our secrets.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Now I'll make a firm trial of your love,
As you love me, not a word more at this time,
Not a syllable, 'tis the seal of love, take heed.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Hum, hum, hum, hum —
Hum's loathe to depart. Exit clown.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: So, this pleasant trouble's gone, now guardianess,
What? your eyes easing your heart, the cause woman?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: The cause is false man, madam, o lady,
I have been gubbed in a shining carbuncle,
A very glow-worm, that I thought had sire in't,
And 'tis as cold as ice.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: And justly served,
Wouldst thou once think that such an erring spring
Would dote upon thine autumn?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: O, had you heard him
But protest.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: I would not have believed him,
Thou mightst have perceived how I mocked thy folly,
In wanton imitation with the fool,
Go weep the sin of thy credulity,
Not of thy loss, for it was never thine,
And it is gain to miss it; wert thou so dull?
Nay yet thou'rt stupid and uncapable,
Why thou wert but the bait to fish with, not
The prey, the stale to catch another bird with.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Indeed he called me bird.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Yet thou perceivest not,
It is your niece he loves, wouldst thou be made
A stakling jade? 'tis she, examine it,
I'll hurry all awry, and tread my path
Over unbeaten grounds, go level to the mark,
Not by circular bouts, rare things are pleasing,
And rare's but seldom in the simple sense,
But has her emphasis with eminenceExit.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: My niece? she the rival of my abuse?
My flesh and blood wrong me? I'll aunt her for't;
O opportunity, thou blessest me
Now gentlewoman, are you parted so soon?
Where's your friend I pray? your Cuningame?

sp.speaker: M●r.
sp.l: What say you aunt?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Come, come, your Cuningame?
I am not blind with age yet, nor deaf.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Dumb I am sure you are not, what ailed you aunt?
Are you not well?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: No, nor sick, nor mad, nor in my wits, nor sleeping, nor walking, nor nothing, nor any thing; I know not what I am, nor what I am not.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Mercy cover us, what do you mean aunt?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: I mean to be revenged.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: On whom?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: On thee, baggage.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Revenge should follow injury,
Which never reached so far as thought in me
Towards you aunt.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Your cunning, minion,
Nor your Cuningame can either blind me,
The gentle beggar loves you.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Beseech you,
Let me stay your error, I begin to hear,
And shake off my amazement; if you think
That ever any passage treating love
Hath been betwixt us yet commenced, any
Silent eye-glance that might but sparkle fire,
So much as brother and sister might meet with,
The lip-salute, so much as strangers might
Take a farewell with, the commixed hands,
Nay, but the least thought of the least of these;
In troth you wrong your bosom, by that truth
(Which I think yet you durst be bail for in me,
If it were offered ye) I am as free
As all this protestation.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: May I believe this?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: If ever you'll believe truth: why, I thought he had spoken love to you, and if his heart prompted his tongue, sure I did hear so much.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: O falsest man, Ixion's plague fell on me,
Never by woman (Such a masculine cloud)
So airy and so subtle was embraced.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: By no cause in me, by my life dear aunt.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: I believe you, then help in my revenge,
And you shall do't, or lose my love for ever,
I'll have him quit at his equal weapon,
Thou art young, follow him, bait his desires
With all the engines of a woman's wit,
Stretch modesty even to the highest pitch;
He cannot freeze at such a flaming beauty;
And when thou hast him by the amorous gills,
Think on my vengeance, choke up his desires,
Then let his banquettings be tantalism,
Let thy disdain spurn the dissembler out;
O I should climb my stars, and sit above,
To see him burn to ashes in his love.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: This will be a strange taste, aunt, and an
Unwilling labour, yet in your injunction
I am a servant to't.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Thou'lt undertake't?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Yes, let the success commend itself hereafter.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Effect it girl, my substance is thy store,
Nothing but want of will makes woman poor. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Why Pompey, thou art not stark mad, art thou?
Wilt thou not tell me how my lady does?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Your lady?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Did she receive the thing that I sent her kindly, or no?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: The thing that you sent her, knight, by the thing that you sent, was for the things sake that was sent to carry the thing that you sent, very kindly received, first, there is your indenture, now go seek you a servant: secondly, you are a knight: thirdly and lastly, I am mine own man: and fourthly, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Why Pompey? prithee let me speak with thee,
I'll lay my life some hair has crossed him.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Knight, if you be a knight, so keep you; as for the lady, who shall say that she is not a fair lady, a sweet lady, an honest and a virtuous lady, I will say he is a base fellow, a blab of his tongue, and I will make him eat these fingers ends.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Why here's nobody says so Pompey.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Whatsoever things have passed between the lady and the other party, whom I will not name at this time, I say she is virtuous, and honest, and I will maintain it, as long as I can maintain myself with bread and water.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Why I know nobody thinks otherwise.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Any man that does but think it in my hearing, I will make him think on't while he has a thought in his bosom; shall we say that kindnesses from ladies are common? or that favours and protestations are things of no moment betwixt parties and parties? I say still, whatsoever has been betwixt the lady and the party which I will not name, that she is honest, and shall be honest, whatsoever she does by day or by night, by light or by darkness, with cut and long tale.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Why I say she is honest.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Is she honest? in what sense do you say she is honest, knight?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: If I could not find in my heart to throw my dagger at thy head, hilts and all, I'm an ass, and no gentleman.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Throw your dagger at me! do not knight, I give you fair warning, 'tis but cast away if you do, for you shall have no other words of me, the lady is an honest lady, whatsoever reports may go of sports and toys, and thoughts, and words, and deeds, betwixt her and the party which I will not name; this I give you to understand, that another man may have as good an eye, as amorous a nose, as fair a stampt beard, and be as proper a man as a knight, (I name no parties) a servingman may be as good as a sir, a Pompey as a Gregory, a doodle as a fop; so servingman Pompey Doodle may be respected as well with ladies (Though I name no parties) as sir Gregory fop; so farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: If the fellow be not out of his wits, then will I never have any more wit while I live; either the sight of the lady has gastered him, or else he's drunk, or else he walks in his sleep, or else he's a fool, or a knave, or both, one of the three I'm sure 'tis; yet now I think on't, she has not used me so kindly as her uncle promised me she should, but that's all one, he says I shall have her, and I dare take his word for the best horse I have, and that's a weightier thing than a lady, I'm sure on't. Exit.

div.stage: Enter lady ruinous (As a man) witty pate, sir ruinous, Priscian, and master credulous, (Binding and robing her, and in scarves) credulous finds the bag.

sp.speaker: Lady Ruin.
sp.l: Nay, I am your own, 'tis in your pleasure
How you'll deal with me; yet I would entreat,
You will not make that which is bad enough,
Worse than it need be, by a second ill,
When it can render you no second profit;
If it be coin you seek, you have your prey,
All my store, I vow, (And it weighs a hundred)
My life, or any hurt you give my body,
Can enrich you no more.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: You may pursue.

sp.speaker: L. Ruin.
sp.l: As I am a gentlewoman, I never will,
Only we'll bind you to quiet behaviour
Till you call out for bail, and on th'other
Side of the hedge leave you; but keep the peace
Till we be out of hearing, for by that
We shall be out of danger, if we come back,
We come with a mischief.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You need not fear me.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.p: Come, we'll bestow you then. Exit ruin. Pris. and lady.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Why la you sir, is not this a swifter revenue then sic probas ergo's and igitur's can bring in? why is not this one of your syllogisms in Barbara? Omne utile est honestum.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Well sir, a little more of this acquaintance,
Will make me know you fully I protest.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: You have (At first sight) made me conscious
Of such a deed my dreams never prompted, yet
I could almost have wished rather you'd robbed me
Of my cloak, (For my purse 'tis a scholar's)
Then to have made me a robber.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: I had rather have answered three difficult questions,
Than this one, as easy as yet it seems.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Tush, you shall never come to further answer for't;
●an you confess your penurious uncle,
〈◊〉 his full face of love, to be so strict
〈◊〉 niggard to your commons, that you are fain
To size your belly out with shoulder fees?
With rumps and kidneys, and cues of single beer,
And yet make dainty to feed more daintily,
At this easier rate? fie master credulous,
I blush for you.

sp.speaker: C●ed.
sp.l: This is a truth undeniable.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Why go to then, I hope I know your uncle,
How does he use his son, nearer than you?

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Faith like his jade, upon the bare commons,
Turned out to pick his living as he can get it;
He would have been glad to have shared in such
A purchase, and thanked his good fortune too;
But mum no more — is all safe, bullies?
Secure? the gentleman thinks him most happy in his loss,
With his safe life and limbs ▪ and redoubles
〈◊〉 first vow, as he is a gentleman,
Never to pursue us.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Well away then,
Disperse you with master credulous, who still
Shall bear the purchase, Priscian and I
Will take some other course: you know our meeting
At the three cups in saint Gyles, with this proviso,
(For 'tis a law with us) that nothing be opened
Till all be present, the looser says a hundred,
And it can weigh no less.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.l: Come, sir, we'll be your guide.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: My honesty, which till now was never forfeited,
All shall be close till our meeting. Exit Cred. and ruin.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Tush, I believe't,
And then all shall out; where's the thief that's robbed?

sp.speaker: L. Ruin.
sp.l: Here master Oldcraft, all follows now.

sp.speaker: W●t.
sp.p: 'Twas neatly done, wench, now to turn that bag 〈◊〉 counterfeits to current pieces, et actum est.

sp.speaker: L. Ruin.
sp.l: You are the chemist, we'll blow the fire still,
If you can mingle the ingredients.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I will not miss a cause, a quantity, a dram,
You know the place.
I have told her that, sir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Good, turn ruinous to be a constable, I'm sure
〈…〉 not beards of all sorts, from the
Worshipful magistrate to the under watchman;
Because we must have no danger of life,
〈◊〉 cleanly cheat, attach credulous,
〈◊〉 cause is plain, the theft found about him;
●●en fall I in his own cousin's shape
〈◊〉 ●eere accident, where finding him distressed,
● with some difficulty must fetch him off,
With promise that his uncle shall shut up all
With double restitution: master Constable, ruinous
His mouth shall be stopped; you, mistress rob thief,
Shall have your share of what we can pull my father of;
Is't plain enough?

sp.speaker: L. Ruin.
sp.l: As plain a cozenage as can be, saith.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Father, I come again, and again when this is
Past too, father, one will beget another;
I'd be loath to leave your posterity barren,
You were best to come to composition father,
Two hundred pieces yearly allow me yet,
It will be cheaper (Father) than my wit,
For I will cheat none but you, dear father.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter old knight and sir Gregory.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Why now you take the course sir Gregory fop:
I could enforce her and I list, but love
That's gently won, is a man's own for ever,
Have you prepared good music?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: As fine a noise, uncle, as heart can wish ▪

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Why that's done like a suitor,
They must be wooed a hundred several ways,
Before you obtain the right way in a woman,
'Tis an odd creature, full of creeks and windings.
The serpent has not more; for sh'as all his,
And then her own beside came in by her mother.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: A fearful portion for a man to venture on.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: But the way found once by the wits of men,
There is no creature lies so tame again.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I promise you, not a house-rabbit, sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: No sucker on 'em all.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: What a thing's that?
They're pretty fools I warrant, when they're tame
As a man can lay his lips to.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: How were you bred, sir?
Did you never make a fool of a tenant's daughter?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Never i'faith, they ha' made some fools for me,
And brought 'em many a time under their aprons.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: They could not show you the way plainlier, I think,
To make a fool again.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: There's fools enough, sir,
Less they were wiser.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: This is wondrous rare,
Come you to London with a maidenhead, knight?
A gentleman of your rank ride with a cloak-bag?
Never an hostess by the way to leave it with?
Nor tapsters sister? nor head ostlers wife?
What nobody ?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Well mocked old wit monger,
I keep it for your niece.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Do not say so for shame, she'll laugh at thee,
A wife never looks for't, 'tis a bachelor's penny,
He may give't to a beggar-wench, i'th progress time,
And never called to account for't. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Would I'd known so much,
I could ha' stopped a beggar's mouth by'th way,
That railed upon me 'cause I'd give her nothing —
What, are they come?

sp.speaker: Pag.
sp.l: And placed directly, sir,
Under her window.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: What may I call you gentleman?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: A poor servant to the viol, I'm the voice, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: In good time master voice.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Indeed good time does get the mastery.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: What countryman master voice?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Sir, born at Ely, we all set up in Ely,
But our house commonly breaks in Rutlandshire .

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: A shrewd place by my faith, it may well break your voice,
It breaks many a man's back; come, set to your business.
Feign would I wake you, sweet, but fear
I should invite you to worse cheer;
In your dreams you cannot fare
Meaner than music; no compare;
None of your slumbers are compiled
Under the pleasure makes a child;
Your day-delights, so well compact,
That what you think, turns all to act:
I'd wish my life no better play,
Your dream by night, your thought by day.
Wake gently, wake,
Part softly from your dreams;
The morning flies
To your fair eyes,
To take her special beams.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I hear her up, here master voice,
Pay you the instruments, save what you can,
To keep you when you're cracked. Exit boy.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Who should this be?
That I'm so much beholding to, for sweetness?
Pray heaven it happens right.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Good morrow mistress.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: An ill day and a thousand come upon thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: 'Light that's six hundred more than any almanac has.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Comes it from thee? it is the mangiest music
That ever woman heard.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Nay say not so lady,
There's not an itch about 'em.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: I could curse
My attentive powers, for giving entrance to't;
There is no boldness like the impudence
That's locked in a fool's blood, how durst you do this?
In conscience I abused you as sufficiently
As woman could a man; insatiate coxcomb,
The mocks, and spiteful language I have given thee,
Would of my life ha' served ten reasonable men,
And rise contented too, and left enough for their friends.
You glutton at abuses, never satisfied?
I am persuaded thou devourest more flouts
Then all thy body's worth, and still a hungered!
A mischief of that maw; prithee seek elsewhere,
Introth I am weary of abusing thee;
Get thee a fresh mistress, thou'lt make work enough;
I do not think there's scorn enough in town
To serve thy turn, take the court ladies in,
And all their women to 'em, that exceed 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Is this in earnest, lady?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: O unsatiable!
Dost thou count all this but an earnest yet?
I'd thought I'd paid thee all the whole sum, trust me;
Thou'lt beggar my derision utterly
If thou stayest longer, I shall want a laugh:
If I knew where to borrow a contempt
Would hold thee tack, stay and be hanged thou shouldst then,
But thou'st no conscience now to extort hate from me,
When one has spent all she can make upon thee;
Must I begin to pay thee hire again?
After I have rid thee twice? faith 'tis unreasonable.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Say you so? I'll know that presently.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Now he runs
To fetch my uncle to this musty bargain,
But I have better ware always at hand.
And lay by this still when he comes to cheapen.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I met the music now, yet cannot learn
What entertainment he received from her.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: There's somebody set already, I must to't, I see,
Well, well, sir Gregory.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Ha, sir Gregory?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Where'er you come you may well boast your conquest.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: She's lost i'faith, enough, has fortune then
Remembered her great boy? she seldom fails 'em.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: He was the unlikeliest man at first, methought ,
To have my love, we never met but wrangled,

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: A pox upon that wrangling, say I still,
I never knew it fail yet, where ere't came;
It never comes but like a storm of hail,
'Tis sure to bring fine weather at the tail on't,
There's not one match 'mongst twenty made without it,
It fights i'th tongue, but sure to agree i'th haunches.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: That man that should ha' told me, when time was,
I should ha' had him, had been laughed at piteously,
But see how things will change?

sp.speaker: Cun,
sp.l: Here's a heart feels it — oh the deceitful promises of love!
What trust should a man put i'th lip of woman?
She kissed me with that strength, as if she'd meant
To ha' set the fair print of her soul upon me.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: I would ha' sworn 'twould never ha' been a match once.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I'll hear no more, I'm mad to hear so much,
Why should I aim my thoughts at better fortunes
Than younger brothers have? that's a maid with nothing,
Or some old soap-boilers widow, without teeth,
There waits my fortune for me, seek no farther.

div.stage: Enter old knight, and sir Gregory.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: You tell me things, sir Gregory, that cannot be,
She will not, nor she dares not.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Would I were whipped then.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: I'll make as little show of love, sir Gregory,
As ever woman did, you shall not know
You have my heart a good while.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Herded you that?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Man will insult so soon, 'tis his condition,
'Tis good to keep him off as long as we can,
I've much ado , I swear; and love i'th end
Will have his course, let maids do what they can,
They are but frail things, till they end in man.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: What say you to this, sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: This is somewhat handsome.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: And by that little wrangling that I feigned,
Now I shall try how constant his love is,
Although't went sore against my heart to chide him.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Alas poor gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Now you're sure of truth,
You hear her own thoughts speak.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: They speak indeed.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Go, you're a brainless Cox, a toy, a fop,
I'll go no farther than your name, sir Gregory,
I'll right myself there; were you from this place,
You should perceive I'm heartily angry with you,
Offer to sow strife 'twixt my niece and I?
Good morrow niece, good morrow.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Many fair ones to you, sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Go, you're a coxcomb. How dost niece this morning?
An idle shallow fool: sleepest thou well, girl?
Fortune may very well provide thee lordships,
For honesty has left thee little manners.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: How am I banged of both sides?

sp.speaker: O.k.
sp.l: Abuse kindness? Wil't take the air today niece?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: When you please, sir,
There stands the heir behind you I must take,
(Which I'd as live take, as take him I swear.)

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: La 'You; do you hear't continued to your teeth now?
A pox of all such Gregory's; what a handNiece lets fall her scarf.
Have I with you?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: No more i'fack, I ha' done, sir:
Lady, your scarf's fallen down.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: 'Tis but your luck, sir,
And does presage the mistress must fall shortly,
You may wear it, and you please.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: There's a trick for you,
You're parlously beloved, you should complain.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Yes, when I complain, sir,
Then do your worst, there I'll deceive you sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: You are a dolt, and so I leave you, sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Ah sirrah, mistress, were you caught i'faith?
We overheard you all; I must not know
I have your heart, take heed a that, I pray,
I knew some scarf would come.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: He's quite gone, sure:
Ah you base coxcomb, couldst thou come again?
And so abused as thou wast?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: 'Twould ha' killed
A sensible man, he would ha' gone to his chamber,
And broke his heart by this time.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Thank you heartily.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Or fixed a naked rapier in a wall,
Like him that earned his knighthood e'er he had it,
And then refused upon't, ran up to'th hilts.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Yes, let him run for me, I was never brought up to't,
I never professed running i' my life.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: What art thou made on? thou tough villainous vermin,
Will nothing destroy thee?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Yes, yes, assure yourself
Unkind words may do much.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Why, dost thou want 'em?
I've e'en consumed my spleen to help thee to 'em,
Tell me what sort of words they be would speed thee?
I'll see what I can do yet.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I'm much beholding to you,
You're willing to bestow huge pains upon me.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: I should account nothing too much to rid thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I wonder you'd not offer to destroy me,
All the while your uncle was here?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Why there thou betrayest thy house, we of the old-crafts
Were born to more wit than so.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I wear your favour here.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Would it might rot thy arm off: if thou knewest
With what contempt thou hast it, what hearts bitterness,
How many cunning curses came along with it,
Thou'dst quake to handle it.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: A pox, take't again then;
Who'd be thus plagued of all hands?

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: No, wear't still,
But long I hope thou shalt not, 'tis but cast
Upon thee, purposely to serve another
That has more right to't, as in some countries they convey
Their treasure upon asses to their friends,
If mine be but so wise and apprehensive
As my opinion gives him to my heart,
It stays not long on thy desertless arm;
I'll make thee ere I ha' done not dare to wear
Any thing of mine, although I give't thee freely;
Kiss it you may, and make what show you can,
But sure you carry't to a worthier man,
And so good morrow to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Hu hum, ha hum;
I han't the spirit now to dash my brains out,
Nor the audacity to kill myself,
But I could cry my heart out, that's as good,
For so't be out no matter which way it comes,
If I can die with a fillip, or depart
At hot cockles, what's that to any man?
If there be so much death that serves my turn there.
Every one knows the state of his own body,
No carrion kills a kite, but then again
There's cheese will choke a daw; time I were dead i'faith,
If I knew which way without hurt or danger.
I am a maiden-knight, and cannot look
Upon a naked weapon with any modesty,
Else 'twould go hard with me, and to complain
To sir perfidious the old knight again,
Were to be more abused; perhaps he would beat me well,
But never believe me;
And few men die a beating, that were lost too:
O, here's my friend, I'll make my moan to him.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I cannot tear her memory from my heart,
That treads mine down, was ever man so fooled
That professed wit?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: O Cuningame?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Sir Gregory?
The choice, the victor, the towns happy man?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Sniggs, what dost mean? come I to thee for comfort, and dost abuse me too?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Abuse you? how sir?
With justifying your fortune, and your joys?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Pray hold your hand, sir I've been bold enough,
You come with a new way now; strike me merrily,
But when a man's sore beaten a both sides already,
Than the least tap in jest goes to the guts on him;
Wilt ha' the truth? I'm made the rankest ass
That e'er was born to lordships.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: What? no sir;

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I had not thought my body could a yielded
All those foul scurvy names that she has called me,
I wonder whence she fetched 'em?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Is this credible?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: She pined this scarf upon me afore her uncle,
But his back turned, she cursed me so for wearing on't,
The very brawn of mine arm has ached ever since,
Yet in a manner forced me to wear't still,
But hoped I should not long; if good luck serve
I should meet one that has more wit and worth
Should take it from me, 'twas but lent to me,
And sent to him for a token.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I conceit it, I know the man
That lies in wait for't, part with't by all means,
In any case, you are waylaid about it.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: How sir? waylaid?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Pox of a scarf say I,
I prize my friend's life above a million on 'em,
You shall be ruled, sir, I know more than you.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: If you know more than I, let me be rid on't,
Lass 'tis not for my wearing, so she told me.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: No, no, give me't, the knave shall miss his purpose,
And you shall live.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I would, as long as I could, sir.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: No more replies, you shall, I'll prevent this,
Pompey shall march without it.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: What, is't he?
My man that was?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Call him your deadly enemy;
You give him too fair a name, you deal too nobly,
He bears a bloody mind, a cruel foe, sir,
I care not if he heard me.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: But do you hear, sir?
Can't sound with reason she should affect him?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Do you talk of reason? I never thought to have heard
Such a word come from you; reason in love?
Would you give that, no doctor could e'er give?
Has not a deputy married his cookmaid?
An alderman's widow one that was her turn broach?
Nay, has not a great lady brought her stable
Into her chamber: lay with her horsekeeper?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Did ever love play such jades tricks, sir?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: O thousands, thousands: beware a sturdy clown ere while you live, sir;
'Tis like a housewifery in most shires about us;
You shall ha' farmers' widows wed thin gentlemen,
Much like yourself, but put 'em to no stress;
What work can they do, with small trapstick legs?
They keep clowns to stop gaps, and drive in pegs,
A drudgery fit for hinds, e'en back again, sir,
You're safest at returning.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Think you so, sir?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: But how came this clown to be called Pompey first?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Push, one good man Caesar, a pump-maker kirsened him;
Pompey he writes himself, but his right name's Pumpey,
And stunk too when I had him, now he's crank.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I'm glad I know so much to quell his pride, sir,
Walk you still that way, I'll make use of this,
To resolve all my doubts, and place this favour
On some new mistress, only for a try,
And if it meet my thoughts, I'll swear 'tis I.Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Is Pompey grown so malepert? so frampold?
The only cutter about ladies' honours?
And his blade soonest out?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Now, what's the news, sir?

sp.speaker: Sir gre.
sp.l: I dare not say but good; o excellent good, sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: I hope now you're resolved she loves you, knight?

sp.speaker: Sir Gr.
sp.l: Cuds me, what else sir? that's not to do now.

sp.speaker: O.k.
sp.l: You would not think how desperately you angered me,
When you belied her goodness; o you vexed me,
Even to a palsy.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: What a thing was that, sir?

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: 'Tis, that 'tis; as I have hope of sweetness, the scarf's gone;
