Worthy wise friend, I dote upon thy cunning,
We two shall be well matched, our issue male, sure
Will be born counsellors; is't possible?
Thou shalt have another token out of hand for't;
Nay since the way's found, pity thou shouldst want, i'faith,
Oh my best joy, and dearest.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Well said, niece,
So violent fore your uncle? what will you do
In secret then?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Marry call me slave, and rascal.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Your scarf — the scarf I gave you —

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Mass that's true niece,
I never thought upon that; the scarf she gave you - sir?
What dumb? no answer from you? the scarf?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I was waylaid about it, my life threatened;
Life's life, scarf's but a scarf, and so I parted from't.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Unfortunate woman! my first favour too?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Will you be still an ass? no reconcilement
Twixt you and wit? are you so far fallen out,
You'll never come together? I tell you true,
I'm very lousily ashamed on you,
That's the worst shame that can be;
Thus baiting on him: now his heart's hooked in,
I'll make him, ere I ha' done, take her with nothing,
I love a man that lives by his wits a life;
Nay leave, sweet niece, 'tis but a scarf, let it go.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: The going of it never grieves me, sir.
It is the manner, the manner —

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: O dissembling marmoset! if I durst speak,
Or could be believed when I speak,
What a tale could I tell, to make hair stand upright now?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Nay, sir, at your request you shall perceive, uncle,
With what renewing love I forgive this?
Here's a fair diamond, sir, I'll try how long
You can keep that?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Not very long, you know't too,
Like a cunning witch as you are.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: You're best let him ha' that too.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: So I were, I think, there were no living else,
I thank you, as you have handled the matter.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Why this is musical now, and Tuesday next
Shall tune your instruments, that's the day set.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: A match, good uncle.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Sir, you hear me too?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: O very well, I'm for you.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Whate'er you hear, you know my mind.

sp.speaker: Sir gre.
sp.p: I a — on't, too well, if I do not wonder how we two shall come together, I'm a bear whelp? he talks of Tuesday next, as familiarly as if we loved one another, but 'tis as unlikely to me, as 'twas seven year before I saw her; I shall try his cunning, it may be he has a way was never yet thought on, and it had need to be such a one, for all that I can think on will never do't; I look to have this diamond taken from me very speedily, therefore I'll take it off a my finger, for if it be seen, I shall be waylaid for that too.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: O.k.
sp.l: O torture! torture! thou carriest a sting i'thy tail,
Thou never broughtest good news i'thy life yet,
And that's an ill quality, leave it when thou wilt.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Why you receive a blessing the wrong way, sir,
Call you not this good news? to save at once sir
Your credit and your kinsman's life together;
Would it not vex your peace, and gall your worth?
To have one of your name hanged?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Peace, no such words, boy.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Be thankful for the blessing of prevention then.

sp.speaker: O.k.
sp.l: Le' me see, there was none hanged out of our house since Brute,
I ha' searched both Stowe, and Hollinshead.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: O sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: I'll see what Polychronicon says anon too.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: 'Twas a miraculous fortune that I heard on't.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: I would thou'dst never heard on't,

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: That's true too,
So it had never been done; to see the luck on't,
He was e'en brought to justice Aurum's threshold,
There had flown forth a mittimus straight for Newgate;
And note the fortune too, sessions a Thursday,
Jury culled out a Friday, judgement a Saturday,
Dungeon a Sunday, Tyburn a Monday,
Misery's quotidian ague, when't begins once,
Every day pulls him, till he pull his last.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: No more, I say, 'tis an ill theme: where left you him?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: He's i'th constable's hands below i'th hall, sir,
Poor gentleman, and his accuser with him.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: What's he?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: A judge's son, 'tis thought so much the worse too,
He'll hang his enemy, an't shall cost him nothing,
That's a great privilege.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Within there?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Call up the folks i'th hall. I had such hope on him,
For a scholar too, a thing thou never wast fit for,
Therefore erected all my joys in him;
Got a Welsh benefice in reversion for him,
Dean of Cardigan, has his grace already,
He can marry and bury, yet never a hair on's face;
sp.stage: Enter credulous, sir ruinous (As a constable,) and lady gentry (As a man.)
sp.l: Like a French vicar, and does he bring such fruits to town with him?
A thief at his first lighting? O good den to you.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Nay, sweet sir, you're so vexed now, you'll grieve him,
And hurt yourself.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Away, I'll hear no counsel;
Come you but once in seven year to your uncle,
And at that time must you be brought home too?
And by a constable?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: O speak low, sir,
Remember your own credit, you profess
You love a man of wit, begin at home, sir,
Express it i' yourself.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Nay, master Constable,
Show yourself a wise man, 'gainst your nature too.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.l: Sir, no dish-porridgement, we have brought home
As good men as ye.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Out, a North-britain constable, that tongue
Will publish all, it speaks so broad already;
Are you the gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: The unfortunate one, sir,
That fell into the power of merciless thieves,
Whereof this fellow, whom I'd call your kinsman,
As little as I could, (For the fair reverence
I owe to fame and years) was the prime villain.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: A wicked prime.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Nay, not so loud, sweet father.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.l: The rest are fled, but I shall meet with 'em,
Hang one of 'em I will certain, I ha' sworn it,
And 'twas my luck to light upon this first.

sp.speaker: O.k.
sp.l: A Cambridge man for this? these your degrees, sir?
Nine years at university for this fellowship?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Take your voice lower, dear sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: What's your loss, sir?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: That which offends me to repeat, the money's whole, sir,
'Tis i' the constable's hands there, a sealed hundred,
But I will not receive it.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: No? not the money, sir,
Having confessed 'tis all?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: 'Tis all the money, sir,
But 'tis not all I lost, for when they bound me,
They took a diamond hung at my shirt string,
Which fear of life made me forget to hide;
It being the sparkling witness of a contract
Betwixt a great lawyer's daughter and myself.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I told you what he was; what does the diamond
Concern my cousin, sir?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: No more did the money,
But he shall answer all now.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: There's your conscience,
It shows from whence you sprung.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sprung? I had leapt a thief,
Had I leapt some of your alliance.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Slave!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: You prevent me still.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: 'Slid, son are you mad?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Come, come, I'll take a legal course.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Will you undo us all? what's your demand, sir?
Now we're in's danger too.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: A hundred mark, sir,
I will not bate a doit.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: A hundred rascals.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: Sir, find 'em out in your own blood, and take 'em.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Go take your course, follow the law, and spare not.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Does fury make you drunk? know you what you say?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: A hundred dogs dungs, do your worst.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: You do I'm sure; who's loud now?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: What his own asking?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Not in such a case?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: You shall have but three score pound; spite a your teeth,
I'll see you hanged first.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: And what's seven pound more man?
That all this coil's about? stay, I say, he shall have't.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: It is your own, you may do what you please with it;
Pardon my zeal, I would ha' saved you money;
Give him all his own asking?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: What's that to you, sir?
Be sparing of your own, teach me to pinch
In such a case as this? go, go, live by your wits, go.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I practise all I can.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Follow you me, sir,
And master Constable come from the knave,
And be a witness of a full recompense.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Pray stop the constable's mouth, whate'er you do. sir

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Yet again? as if I meant not to do that myself,
Without your counsel? As for you, precious kinsman,
Your first year's fruits in Wales shall go to rack for this,
You lie not in my house, I'll pack you out,
And pay for your lodging rather. Exeunt knight, ruin. and lady.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: O fie cousin,
These are ill courses, you a scholar too,

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: I was drawn into't most unfortunately,
By filthy deboyst company.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Ay, ay, ay,
'Tis even the spoil of all our youth in England;
What were they gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Faith so like, some on 'em,
They were e'en the worse again.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Hum.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Great tobacco swivers,
They would go near to rob with a pipe in their mouths.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: What, no?

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Faith leave it cousin, because my rascals use it,

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: So they do meat and drink, must worthy gentlemen
Refrain their food for that? an honest man
May eat of the same pig some parson dines with,
A lawyer and a fool feed of one woodcock,
Yet one never the simpler, tother never the wiser;
'Tis not meat, drink, or smoke, dish, cup, or pipe,
Co-operates to the making of a knave,
'Tis the condition makes a slave, a slave,
There's London philosophy for you; I tell you cozen,
You cannot be too cautelous, nice, or dainty,
In your society here, especially
When you come raw from the university,
Before the world has hardened you a little,
For as a buttered loaf is a scholar's breakfast there,
So a poached scholar is a cheater's dinner here,
I ha' known seven of 'em supped up at a meal.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Why a poached scholar?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: 'Cause he pours himself forth,
And all his secrets, at the first acquaintance,
Never so crafty to be eaten i'th shell,
But is outstripped of all he has at first,
And goes down glib, he's swallowed with sharp wit,
Stead of wine vinegar.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: I shall think, cousin,
A' your poch't scholar, while I live.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Master credulous,
Your uncle wills you to forbear the house,
You must with me, I'm charged to see you placed
In some new lodging about thieving lane,
What the conceit's, I know not, but commands you
To be seen here no more, till you hear further.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Here's a strange welcome, sir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: This is the world, cousin;
When a man's fame's once poisoned, fare thee well lad.
This is the happiest cheat I e'er claimed share in,
It has a two fold fortune, gets me coin,
And puts him out of grace, that stood between me,
My father's Cambridge jewel, much suspected
To be his heir, now there's a bar in's hopes.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.l: It chinks, make haste.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: The goat at Smithfield pens.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Zo, zo, sufficient. Master Cunningame?
I never have ill luck when I meet a wit.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: A wit's better to meet, than to follow then,
For I ha' none so good I can commend yet,
But commonly men unfortunate to themselves,
Are luckiest to their friends, and so may I be.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I run o'er so much worth, going but in haste from you,
All my deliberate friendship cannot equal.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: 'Tis but to show that you can place sometimes,
Your modesty a top of all your virtues. Exit wit.
This gentleman may pleasure me yet again;
I am so haunted with this broad brimmed hat,
Of the last progress block, with the young hatband,
Made for a sucking devil of two year old,
I know not where to turn myself.

sp.speaker: Mir,
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: More torture?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: 'Tis rumoured that you love me.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: A my troth gentlewoman,
Rumour's as false a knave as ever pissed then,
Pray tell him so from me; I cannot feign
With a sweet gentlewoman, I must deal down right.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I heard, though you dissembled with my aunt, sir,
And that makes me more confident.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: There's no falsehood,
But pays us our own some way, I confess
I feigned with her, 'twas for a weightier purpose,
But not with thee, I swear.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Nor I with you then,
Although my aunt enjoined me to dissemble,
To right her spleen, I love you faithfully.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Light, this is worse than 'twas.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I find such worth in you,
I cannot, nay I dare not dally with you,
For fear the flame consume me.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Here's fresh trouble,
This drives me to my conscience, for 'tis foul
To injure one that deals directly with me.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I crave but such a truth from your love, sir,
As mine brings you, and that's proportionable.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: A good geometrician, shrew my heart;
Why are you out of your wits, pretty plump gentlewoman,
You talk so desperately? 'tis a great happiness,
Love has made one on's wiser than another,
We should be both cast away else;
Yet I love gratitude, I must requite you,
I shall be sick else, but to give you me,
A thing you must not take, if you mean to live,
For of my troth I hardly can myself;
No wise physician will prescribe me for you.
Alas your state is weak, you had need of cordials
Some rich electuary, made of a son an heir,
An elder brother in a cullis, whole,
'T must be some wealthy Gregory, boiled to a jelly,
That must restore you to the state of new gowns,
French ruffs, and mutable head tires,

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: But where is he, sir?
One that's so rich will never wed me with nothing.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Then see thy conscience and thy wit together,
Wouldst thou have me then, that has nothing neither?
What say you to fop Gregory the first yonder?
Will you acknowledge your time amply recompensed?
Full satisfaction upon love's record?
Without any more suit, if I combine you?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Yes, by this honest kiss.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: You're a wise client,
To pay your fee before hand, but all do so,
You know the worst already, that's thee best too.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I know he's a fool,

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: You're shrewdly hurt then;
This is your comfort, your great wisest women
Pick their first husband still out of that house,
And some will have 'em to choose, if they bury 20.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I'm of their minds, that like him for a first husband,
To run youths race with him, 'tis very pleasant,
But when I'm old, I'd always wish a wiser.
You may have me by that time; for this first business,
Rest upon my performance.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: With all thankfulness.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I have a project you must aid me in too.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You bind me to all lawful action, sir,
Pray wear this scarf about you;
I conjecture now —

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: There's a court principle for't, one office must help another;
As for example, for your cast a Manchits out a'th pantry,
I'll allow you a goose out a'th kitchen.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: 'Tis very sociably done, sir, farewell performance,
I shall be bold to call you so.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Do, sweet confidence,
If I can match my two broad brimmed hats;
'Tis he, I know the maggot by his head;
Now shall I learn news of him, my precious chief.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I have been seeking for you i'th bowling green,
Enquired at Nettleton's, and Anthony's ordinary,
'Thas vexed me to the heart, look, I've a diamond here,
And it cannot find a master.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: No? That's hard i'faith.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: It does belong to somebody , a — on him,
I would he had it, does but trouble me,
And she that sent it, is so waspish too,
There's no returning to her till't be gone.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: O, ho, ah sirrah, are you come?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: What's that friend?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Do you note that corner sparkle?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Which? which? which sir?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: At the West end a'the collar.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: O I see't now.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: 'Tis an apparent mark; this is the stone, sir,
That so much blood is threatened to be shed for.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I pray?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: A ton at least.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: They must not find't I'm then, they must
Go where 'tis to be had.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: 'Tis well it came to my hands first, sir Gregory,
I know where this must go.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Am I discharged on't?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: My life for yours now. Draws.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: What now?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: 'Tis discretion, sir,
I'll stand upon my guard all the while I have't.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Troth thou takest too much danger on thee still,
To preserve me alive.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: 'Tis a friend's duty, sir,
Nay, by a toy that I have late thought upon,
I'll undertake to get your mistress for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Thou wilt not? wilt?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Contract her by a trick, sir,
When she least thinks on't.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: There's the right way to't,
For if she think on't once, she'll never do't.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: She does abuse you still then?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: A — damnably,
Every time worse than other; yet her uncle
Thinks the day holds a Tuesday; say it did, sir,
She's so familiarly used to call me rascal,
She'll quite forget to wed me by my own name,
And then that marriage cannot hold in law, you know.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Will you leave all to me?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Who should I leave it to?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: 'Tis our luck to love nieces; I love a niece too.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I would you did i'faith.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: But mine's a kind wretch.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I marry sir, I would mine were so too.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: No rascal comes in her mouth.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Troth, and mine has little else in hers.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Mine sends me tokens,
All the world knows not on.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Mine gives me tokens too, very fine tokens,
But I dare not wear 'em.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Mine's kind in secret.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: And there mine's a hellcat.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: We have a day set too.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: 'Slid, so have we man,
But there's no sign of ever coming together.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Tell thee who 'tis, the old woman's niece.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Is't she?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I would your luck had been no worse for mildness;
But mum, no more words on't to your lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Foh!

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: No blabbing as you love me.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: None of our blood
Were ever babblers.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Prithee convey this letter to her,
But at any hand let not your mistress see't.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Yet again sir?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: There's a jewel in't,
The very art would make her dote upon't.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Say you so?
And she shall see't for that trick only.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Remember but your mistress, and all's well.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Nay if I do not hang me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I believe you;
This is the only way to return a token,
I know he will do't now, cause he's charged to'th contrary.
He's the nearest kin to a woman, of a thing
Made without substance, that a man can find again,
Some petticoat begotten him, I'll be whipped else,
Engendering with an old pair of pawned hose,
Lying in some hot chamber o'er the kitchen,
Very steam bred him,
He never came where remembering in re e'er grew;
The generation of a hundred such
Cannot make a man stand in a white sheet,
For 'tis no act in law, nor can a constable
Pick out a bawdy business for Bridewell in't;
A lamentable case, he's got with a man's urine, like a mandrake.
How now? hah? what prodigious bravery's this?
A most preposterous gallant, the doublet sits
As if it mocked the breeches.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Save you, sir,

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Has put his tongue in the fine suit of words too.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: How does the party?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Takes me for a scrivener. Which of the parties?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Hum, simplicity betide thee —
I would fain hear of the party; I would be loath to go
Further with her; honour is not a thing to be dallied withal,
No more is reputation, no nor fame, I take it, I must not
Have her wronged when I'm abroad, my party is not
To be compelled with any party in an oblique way;
'Tis very dangerous to deal with women;
May prove a lady too, but shall be nameless,
I'll bite my tongue out, ere it prove a traitor.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Upon my life I know her.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Not by me,
Know what you can, talk a whole day with me,
You're never the wiser, she comes not from these lips.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: The old knight's niece.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: 'Slid he has got her, pox of his heart that told him,
Can nothing be kept secret? let me entreat you
To use her name as little as you can, though.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: 'Twill be small pleasure, sir, to use her name.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I had intelligence in my solemn walks,
Betwixt Paddington and Pancridge, of a scarf,
Sent for a token, and a jewel followed,
But I acknowledge not the receipt of any,
Howe'er 'tis carried, believe me sir,
Upon my reputation I received none.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: What, neither scarf nor jewel?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: 'Twould be seen
Somewhere about me, you may well think that,
I have an arm for a scarf, as others have,
And dare to hang a jewel too, and that's more
Than some men have, my betters a great deal,
I must have restitution, where'er it lights.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: And reason good.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: For all these tokens, sir,
Pass i' my name.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: It cannot otherwise be.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Sent to a worthy friend.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Ay, that's to thee.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I'm wronged under that title.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I dare swear thou art,
'Tis nothing but sir Gregory's circumvention,
His envious spite, when thou'rt at Paddington,
He meets the gifts at Pancridge.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Ah false knight?
False both to honour, and the law of arms?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: What wilt thou say if I be revenged for thee?
Thou sit as witness?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I should laugh in state then.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I'll fob him, here's my hand.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I should be as glad as any man alive, to see him well fobbed, sir; but now you talk of fobbing, I wonder the lady sends not form according to promise? I ha' kept out a town these two days, a purpose to be sent for; I am almost starved with walking.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Walking gets men a stomach.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: 'Tis most true, sir, I may speak it by experience, for I ha' got a stomach six times, and lost it again, as often as a traveller from Chelsy shall lose the sight of Paul's, and get it again.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Go to her, man.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Not for a million, infringe my oath? there's a toy called a vow, has passed between us, a poor trifle, sir; pray do me the part and office of a gentleman, if you chance to meet a footman by the way, in orange tawny ribbons, running before an empty coach, with a buzzard i'th poop on't, direct him and his horses towards the new river by Islington, there they shall have me looking upon the pipes, and whistling. Exit Clow.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: A very good note; this love makes us all monkeys,
But to my work: scarf first? and now a diamond? these
Should be sure signs of her affection's truth;
Yet I'll go forward with my surer proof. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Is't possible?
Nay here's his letter too, there's a fine jewel in't,
Therefore I brought it to you.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: You tedious mongrill! Is't not enough
To grace thee, to receive this from thy hand,
A thing which makes me almost sick to do,
But you must talk too?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I ha' done

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Fall back,
Yet backer, backer yet, you unmannerly puppy,
Do you not see I'm going about to read it?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Nay these are golden days, now I stay by't,
She was wont not to endure me in her sight at all,
The world mends, I see that.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: What an ambiguous superscription's here?
To the best of nieces. Why that title may be mine,
And more than here's:
Sure I much wrong the neatness of his art;
'Tis certain sent to me, and to requite
My cunning in the carriage of my tokens,
Used the same fop for his.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: She nodded now to me, 'twill come in time.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: What's here? an entire ruby, cut into a heart.
And this the word, istud amoris opus?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I have heard him say that love is the best stone-cutter.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Why thou saucy issue of some travelling sowgelder,
What makes love? thy mouth? is it a thing
That ever will concern thee? I do wonder
How thou dar'st think on't? hast thou ever hope
To come i' the same room where lovers are;
And scape unbrained with one of their velvet slippers?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Love tricks break out I see, and you talk of slippers once,
'Tis not far off to bed time.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Is it possible thou canst laugh yet?
I would ha' undertook to ha' killed a spider
With less venom far, than I have spit at thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: You must conceive,
A knights another manner a piece of flesh.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Back, owls face.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Do, do.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: 'Tis my uncle's voice, that:
Why keep you so far off, sir Gregory?
Are you afraid, sir, to come near your mistress?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Is the proud heart come down? I looked for this still.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: He comes not this way yet: away, you dog-whelp;
Would you offer to come near me, though I said so?
I'll make you understand my mind in time;
Your running greedily like a hound to his breakfast,
That chops in head and all to beguile his fellows;
I'm to be eaten, sir, with grace and leisure,
Behaviour and discourse, things that never trouble you;
After I have pelted you sufficiently,
I trow you will learn more manners.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I'm wondering still when we two shall come together?
Tuesday's at hand, but I'm as far off, as I was at first,
I swear.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Now Cuningame, I'll be revenged at large:
Lady, what was but all this while suspicion,
Is truth, full blown now, my niece wears your scarf.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Ha?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Do but follow me, I'll place you instantly
Where you shall see her courted by Cuningame.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: I go with greediness; we long for things
That break our hearts sometimes, there's pleasure's misery,

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Where are those gadflies going? to some junket now;
That some old humble-bee tolls the young one forth
To sweet meats after kind, let 'em look to't,
The thing you wot on, be not missed or gone,
I bring a maidenhead, and I look for one. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Cunningame (In discourse with a masked gentlewoman in a broad hat and scarved,) niece at another door.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Yes, yes.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Too manifest now, the scarf and all.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: It cannot be, you're such a fearful soul.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: I'll give her cause of fear ere I part from her.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Will you say so? Is't not your aunt's desire too?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.p: What a dissembling groan's that? she'll forswear't now.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I see my project takes, yonder's the grace on't.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Who would put confidence in wit again,
I'm plagued for my ambition, to desire
A wise man for a husband, and I see
Fate will not have us go beyond our stint,
We are allowed but one dish, and that's woodcock,
It keeps up wit to make us friends and fervants of,
And thinks any thing's good enough to make us husbands
O that whores hat of thine, of the riding block,
A shade for lecherous kisses.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Make you doubt on't?
Is not my love of force?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Yes, me it forces
To tear that sorcerous strumpet from th'imbraces.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Lady?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: O thou hast wronged the exquisitest love —

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: What mean you lady?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Mine, you'll answer for't.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Alas, what seek you?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Sir, mine own with loss.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: You shall.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: I never made so hard a bargain.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Sweet lady?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Unjust man, let my wrath reach her,
As you owe virtue duty; your cause trips you,
Now minion, you shall feel what loves rage is,
Before you taste the pleasure; smile you false, sir?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: How can I choose? to see what pains you take,
Upon a thing will never thank you for't?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: See what things you women be, lady,
When clothes are taken for the best part of you?
This was to show you, when you think I love you not,
How you're deceived still, there the moral lies,
'Twas a trap set to catch you, and the only bait
To take a lady nibbling, is fine clothes;
Now I dare boldly thank you for your love,
I'm pretty well resolved in't by this fit,
For a jealous ague always ushers it.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Now blessings still maintain this wit of thine,
And I'm an excellent fortune coming in thee,
Bring nothing else I charge thee.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Not a groat I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Thou shalt be worthily welcome, take my faith for't,
Next opportunity shall make us.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: The old gentlewoman has fooled her revenge sweetly.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Lass 'tis her part, she knows her place so well yonder;
Always when women jump upon three score,
Love shoves 'em from the chamber to the door.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Thou art a precious she-wit. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.
div.stage: Enter Cunningame (At one door) winy pate, ruinous, L. Ruinous, and Priscian (At the other.)

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Friend, met in the harvest of our designs,
Not a thought but's busy.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I knew it man,
That made me provide these needful reapers,
Hooks, rakers, gleaners; we'll sing it home
With a melodious hornpipe; this is the bond,
That as we further in your great affair,
You'll suffer us to glean, pick up for crumbs,
And if we snatch a handful from the sheaf,
You will not look a churl on's.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Friend, we'll share
The sheaves of gold, only the love acre
Shall be peculiar.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Much good do you, sir,
Away, you know your way, and your stay; get you
The music ready, while we prepare the dancers.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.l: We are a consort of ourselves.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: And can strike up lustily.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: You must bring sir fop.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: That's perfect enough.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.l: Bring all the fops you can, the more the better fare,
So the proverb runs backwards. Exeunt ruin. And Pris.

sp.speaker: L. Ruin.
sp.l: I'll bring the ladies. Exit.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Do so first, and then the fops will follow;
I must to my father, he must make one. Exit.

div.stage: Enter two servants with a banquet.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: While I dispatch a business with the knight,
And I go with you. Well said, I thank you,
This small banquet will furnish our few guests
With taste and state enough; one reach my gown,
The action craves it rather than the weather.

sp.speaker: 1 serv.
sp.l: There's one stays to speak with you sir.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: What is he?

sp.speaker: 1 serv.
sp.l: Faith I know not what, sir, a fool I think,
That some broker's shop has made half a gentleman;
Has the name of a worthy too ..

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Pompey? is't not?

sp.speaker: 1 serv.
sp.l: That's he, sir.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Alas poor fellow, prithee enter him, he will need too,
sp.stage: Enter second servant with a gown.
sp.l: He shall serve for a witness. O gramercy:
If my friend sir Gregory comes, you know him,
Entertain him kindly. O master Pompey, how is't man?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: 'Snailes, I'm almost starved with love, and cold, and one thing or other;
Has not my lady sent for me yet?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Not that I hear, sure some unfriendly messenger is employed betwixt you,

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I was never so cold in my life, in my conscience I have been seven mile in length, along the new river; I have seen a hundred stickle bags; I do not think but there's gudgeons too; 'twill never be a true water.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Why think you so?

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I warrant you, I told a thousand miller's thumbs in it,
I'll make a little bold with your sweetmeats.
And welcome Pompey.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: 'Tis is a strange thing, I have no taste in any thing.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: O, that's love, that distastes any thing but itself.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: 'Tis worse than cheese in that point, may not a man break his word with a lady? I could find in my heart and my hose too.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: By no means sir, that breaks all the laws of love.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Well, I'll never pass my word without my deed to lady, while I live again, I would fain recover my taste.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Well, I have news to tell you.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Good news, sir?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Happy news, I help you away with a rival your master bestowed

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Where for this plumbs sake —

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Nay listen me.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I warrant you, sir, I have two ears to one mouth,
I hear more than I eat, I'd never row by Queen hive
While lived else.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I have a wife for him, and that shall witness the contract.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: The old one I hope, 'tis not the lady?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Choke him first, 'tis one which thou shalt see,
See him, see him deceived, see the deceit, only
The injunction is, you shall smile with modesty.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I'll simper i'faith, as cold as I am yet, the old one I hope.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.l: Sir, here's sir Gregory.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Ud'so shelter, shelter, if you be seen
All's ravelled out again; stand there private,
And you'll find the very opportunity
To call you forth, and place you at the table.
You are welcome sir, this banquet will serve,
When it is crowned with such a dainty as you
Expect, and must have.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Tush, these sweetmeats are but sauce to that,
Well, if there be any honesty or true word in a dream,
She's mine own, nay, and changed extremely,
Not the same woman.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Who? not the lady?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg,
sp.l: No, not to me, the edge of her tongue is taken off,
Gives me very good words, turned upside down to me,
And we live as quietly as two tortoises, if she hold on
As she began in my dream. Soft music.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Nay, if love send forth such predictions,
You are bound to believe 'em, there's the watchword
Of her coming, to your practised part now,
If you hit it, aequus cupido nobis.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: I will warrant you sir, I will give arms to
Your gentry, look you forward to your business,
I am an eye behind you, place her in that chair,
And let me alone to grope her out.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Silence, lady, your sweet presence illustrates
This homely roof, and as course entertainment;
But where affections are both host and guest,
They cannot meet unkindly, please you fit,
Your something long stay made me unmannerly,
To place before you, you know this friend here,
He's my guest, and more especially,
That this our meeting might not be too single,
Without a witness to't.

sp.speaker: Mirab.
sp.l: I came not unresolved, sir,
And when our hands are clasped in that firm faith
Which I expect from you; fame shall be bold
To speak the loudest on't: o, you grasp me.
Somewhat too hard friend.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: That's loves eager will,
I'll touch it gentlier. Kiss her hand.

sp.speaker: Mirab.
sp.l: That's too low in you,
Less it be doubly recompensed in me. She kisses his hand.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Puh, I must stop my mouth, I shall be choked else.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Come, we'll not play and trifle with delays,
We met to join these hands, and willingly
I cannot leave it till confirmation.

sp.speaker: Mirab.
sp.p: One word first, how does your friend, kind sir Gregory?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Why do you mention him? you love him not?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I shall love you the less if you say so, sir,
In troth I love him, but 'tis you deceive him,
This flattering hand of yours does rob him now,
Now you steal his right from him, and I know
I shall have hate for't, his hate extremely.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Why I thought you had not come so weakly armed,
Upon my life the knight will love you for't,
Exceedingly love you, for ever love you.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Ay, you'll persuade me so.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Why he's my friend,
And wishes me a fortune equal with him,
I know, and dare speak it for him.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: O, this hand betrays him, you might remember him in some courtesy yet at least.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I thank your help in't, here's to his health
Where'er he be.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I'll pledge it were it against my health.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Oh. O, my heart hops after twelve mile a day, upon a good return, now could I walk three hundred mile a foot, and laugh forwards and backwards.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: You'll take the knight's health sir,

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Yes, yes forsooth, o my sides! such a banquet once a week, would make me grow fat in a fortnight.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Well, now to close our meeting, with the close
Of mutual hands and hearts, thus I begin,
Here in heaven's eye, and all love's sacred powers,
(Which in my prayers stand propitious)
I knit this holy hand fast, and with this hand
The heart that owes this hand, ever binding
By force of this initiating contract
Both heart and hand in love, faith, loyalty,
Estate, or what to them belongs, in all the dues;
Rights and honours of a faithful husband,
And this firm vow henceforth till death to stand
Irrevocable, sealed both with heart and hand.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Which thus I second, but o, sir Gregory.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Again? this interposition's ill, believe me.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Here in heaven's eye, and all loves sacred powers
I knit this holy hand fast, and with this hand
The heart that owes this hand, ever binding
Both heart and hand in love, honour, loyalty,
Estate, or what to them belongs in all the dues,
Rights, and duties of a true faithful wife;
And this firm vow henceforth till death to stand,
Irrevocable sealed both with heart and hand.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: A full agreement on both parts.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Ay, here's witness of that.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Nay, I have overreached you lady, and that's much,
For any knight in England to overreach a lady.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I rejoice in my deceit, I am a lady
Now, I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Good morrow lady fop.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: 'snailes, I'm gulled, made a worshipful ass, this is not my lady.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: But it is sir, and true as your dream told you,
That your lady was become another woman.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I'll have another lady sir, if there were no more ladies in London, blindman buff is an unlawful game.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Come, down on your knees first, and thank your stars.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: A fire of my stars, I may thank you I think.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: So you may pray for me, and honour me,
That have preserved you from a lasting torment,
For a perpetual comfort; did you call me friend?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I pray pardon me for that, l did miscall you, I confess.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: And should I receiving such a thankful name
Abuse it in the act? should I see my friend
Baffled, disgraced, without any reverence
To your title to be called slave, rascal?
Nay cursed to your face, fooled, scorned, beaten down
With a woman's peevish hate, yet I should stand
And suffer you to be lost, cast away?
I would have seen you buried quick first,
Your spurs of knighthood to have wanted rowels,
And to be kicked from your heels; slave, rascal?
Hear this tongue?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: My dearest love, sweet knight, my lord, my husband.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: So, this is not slave and rascal then.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: What shall your eye command, but shall be done,
In all the duties of a loyal wife?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Good, good, are not curses fitter for you? were't not better
Your head were broke with the handle of a fan,
Or your nose bored with a silver bodkin?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Why, I will be a servant in your lady.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Pox, but you shall not, she's too good for you,
This contract shall be a nullity, I'll break't off,
And see you better bestowed.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: 'Slid, but you shall not sir, she's mine own, and I am hers, and we are one another's lawfully, and let me see him that will take her away by the civil law, if you be my friend keep you so, if you have done me a good turn, do not hit me ith' teeth with't, that's not the part of a friend.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: If you be content —

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Content? I was never in better contention in my life,
I'll not change her for both the exchanges, new or the old;
Come, kiss me boldly.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: Give you joy, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: O sir, I thank you as much as though I did, you are beloved of ladies, you see we are glad of under women.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Ladies? let not ladies be disgraced, you are as it were a married man, and have a family, and for the party's sake that was unnamed before, being pees-cod time, I am appeased, yet I would wish you make a ruler of your tongue.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Nay, no dissension here, I must bar that,
And this (Friend) I entreat you, and be advised,
Let this private contract be yet concealed,
And still support a seeming face of love
Unto the lady; mark how it avails you,
And quits all her scorns, her uncle is now hot
In pursuit of the match, and will enforce her
Bend her proud stomach, that she shall proffer
Herself to you, which when you have flouted,
And laughed your fill at, you shall scorn her off
With all your disgraces trebled upon her,
For there the pride of all her heart will bow,
When you shall foot her from you, not she you.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Good i'faith; I'll continue it, I'd fain laugh at the old fellow too, for he has abused me as scurvily as his niece, my knighthood's upon the spur, we'll go to bed, and then to church as fast as we can.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.l: I do wonder I do not hear of the lady yet.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: The good minute may come sooner than you are aware of,
I do not think but 'twill ere night yet as near as 'tis.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Well, I will go walk by the new river in that meditation, I am o'er shoes I'm sure upon the dry bank, this gullery of my master will keep me company this two hours too, if love were not an enemy to laughter I should drive away the time well enough; you know my walk sir, if she sends, I shall be found angling, for I will try what I can catch for luck's sake, I will fish fair for't.
sp.l: O knight that thou shouldst be gulled so; ha, ha, it does me good at heart,
But o lady, thou takest down my merry part. exit

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Friend.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Here friend.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: All's afoot, and will go smooth away,
The woman has conquered the women, they are gone,
Which I have already complained to my father,
Suggesting that sir Gregory is fallen off
From his charge, for neglects and ill usage,
And that he is most violently bent
On gentry's wife (Whom I have called a widow)
And that without most sudden prevention
He will be married to her.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Foot, all this is wrong,
This wings his pursuit, and will be before me; I am lost for ever.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: No, stay, you shall not go
But with my father, on my wit let it lie,
You shall appear a friendly assistant,
To help in all affairs, and in execution
Help yourself only.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Would my belief
Were strong in this assurance.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: You shall credit it,
And my wit shall be your slave if it deceive you.
My father —

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: O sir, you are well met, where's the knight your friend?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Sir, I think your son has told you.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Shall I stand to tell't again? I tell you he loves,
But not my kinswoman, her base usage,
And your slack performance which he accuses most
Indeed, has turned the knight's heart upside down.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: I'll curb her for't, can he be but recovered,
He shall have her, and she shall be dutiful,
And love him as a wife too.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: With that condition sir,
I dare recall him were he entered the church,
So much interest of love I assure in him.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Sir, it shall be no loss to you if you do.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Ay, but these are words still, will not the deeds be wanting at the recovery, if it should be again?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Why here fool, I am provided, five hundred in earnest,
Of the thousands in her dower, but were they married once,
I'd cut him short enough, that's my agreement.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Ay, now I perceive some purpose in you, father.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: But wherefore is she then stolen out of doors to him?

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: To him? o fie upon your error, she has another object, believe it sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: I never could perceive it.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: I did sir, and to her shame I should speak it,
To my own sorrow I saw it, dalliance,
Nay dotage with a very clown, a fool.

sp.speaker: O.k.
sp.l: Wit and wantoness? nothing else? nothing else?
She love a fool? she'll sooner mate a fool
Of a wise man.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Ay, my friend complains so,
Sir Gregory says flatly she makes a fool of him,
And these bold circumstances are approved;
Favours have been sent by him, yet he ignorant
Whither to carry 'em; they have been understood,
And taken from him, certain sir, there is
An unsuspected fellow lies concealed,
What, or where'er he is, these slight neglects
Could not be of a knight else.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: Well sir, you have promised (If we recover him unmarried) to salve all these old bruises?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I'll do my best sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: I shall thank you, costly sir, and kindly too.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Will you talk away the time here sir, and come behind all your purposes?

sp.speaker: O.k.
sp.l: Away good sir.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Then stay a little good sir, for my advice,
Why father are you broke? your wit beggared,
Or are you at your wit's end? or out of
Love with wit? no trick of wit to surprise
Those designs, but with open hue and cry,
For all the world to talk on? this is strange,
You were not wont to slubber a project so.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Can you help at a pinch now? show yourself
My son, go too, I leave this to your wit,
Because I'll make a proof on't.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: 'Tis thus then,
I have had late intelligence, they are now
Buxom as Bacchus froes, revelling, dancing,
Telling the music's numbers with their feet,
Awaiting the meeting of premonished friends,
That's questionless, little dreading you,
Now sir, with a dexterous trick indeed, sudden
And sufficient were well, to enter on 'em
As something like the abstract of a masque;
What though few persons? if best for our purpose
That commends the project.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: This takes up time.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Not at all, I can presently furnish
With loose disguises that shall fit that scene.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Why what wants then?

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Nothing but charge of music,
That must be paid you know.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: That shall be my charges, I'll pay the music,
Whate'er it cost.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: And that shall be all your charge,
Now on, I like it, there will be wit in't father.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: I will neither distrust his wit nor friendship,
Yet if his master brain should be o'erthrown
My resolution now shall seize mine own.Exit

div.stage: Enter niece, lady ruinous, gardianesse, ruinous, Priscian (With instrument masqued.

sp.speaker: L. Ruin.
sp.l: Nay, let's have music, let that sweet breath at least
Give us her airy welcome, 'twill be the best
I fear this ruined receptacle will yield,
But that most freely.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: My welcome follows me,
Else I am ill come hither, you assure me
Still Mr. Cuningame will be here, and that it was
His kind entreaty that wished me meet him.

sp.speaker: L. Ruin.
sp.l: Else let me be that shame unto my sex,
That all belief may fly 'em.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Continue still
The knight's name unto my guardianess,
She expects no other.

sp.speaker: L. Ruin.
sp.l: He will, he will assure you
Lady, sir Gregory will be here, and suddenly
This music foreran him, is't not so consorts?

sp.speaker: Ruin,
sp.l: Yes lady, he stays on some device to bring along
Such a labour he was busy in, some witty device.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.p: 'Twill be long ere he comes then, for wit's a great labour to him.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Well, well, you'll agree better one day.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Scarce two I think.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Such a mock-beggar suit of clothes as led me
Into the fool's pair of dice, with deuce ace,
He that would make me mistress Cun, Cun, coney,
He's quite out of my mind, but I shall never
Forget him while I have a hole in my head,
Such a one I think would please you better,
Though he did not abuse you.

sp.speaker: Ruin,
sp.l: Fie, speak well of him now,
Your niece has quit him.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: I hope she has,
Else she loses me for ever; but for sir Gregory,
Would he were come. I shall ill answer this
Unto your uncle else.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: You know 'tis his pleasure
I should keep him company.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Ay, and should be your own
If you did well too, lord, I do wonder
At the niceness of you ladies nowadays ,
They must have husbands with so much wit forsooth.
Worship and wealth were both wont to be
In better request I'm sure, I cannot tell,
But they get never the wiser children that I see.

sp.speaker: L. Ruin.
sp.l: La, la, la, la, sol, this music breathes in vain,
Methinks 'tis dull to let it move alone,
Let's have a female motion, 'tis in private,
And we'll grace't ourselves however it deserves.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: What say you guardianess?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Alas I'm weary with the walk,
My jaunting days are done.

sp.speaker: L. Ruin.
sp.l: Come, come, we'll fetch her in by course, or else,
She shall pay the music.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Nay, I'll have a little for my money then.

div.stage: The dance, a cornet is winded.

sp.speaker: L. Ruin.
sp.l: Hark? upon my life the knight; 'tis your friend,
This was the warning-piece of his approach.

div.stage: Enter old knight, Witty-pate, Cuningame, masqued, and take them to dance.

sp.speaker: L. Ruin.
sp.l: Ha? no words but mum? well then,
We shall need no counsell-keeping

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Cuningame?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Yes, fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Fear? why do you tell me of it?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Your uncles here.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Ay me.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: We have caught 'em.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Thank my wit father.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Which is the knight think you?

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: I know not, he will be found when be speaks,
No mask can disguise his tongue.

sp.speaker: Wity.
sp.l: Are you charged?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Are you awake?

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: I'm answered in a question.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Next change we meet, we lose our hands no more.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Are you prepared to tie 'em?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: Yes,
You must go with me.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Whether sir? not from my charge believe me.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: She goes a long.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.l: Will you venture and my uncle here?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: His stay's prepared for. Exeunt they two.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: 'Tis the knight sure, I'll follow.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: How now, the music tired before us?

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.l: Yes sir, we must be paid now.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: O, that's my charge father.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: But stay, where are our wanton ladies gone?
Son, where are they?

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Only changed the room in a change, that's all sure.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: I'll make 'em all sure else, and then return to you.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.l: You must pay for your music first, sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Must? are there musty fiddlers? are beggars choosers now?
Ha? why witty-pate, son, where am I?

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: You were dancing e'en now, in good measure sir,
Is your health miscarried since? what ail you, sir?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Death, I may be gulled to my face, where's my niece?
What are you?

sp.speaker: L. Ruin.
sp.l: None of your niece, sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: How now? have you loud instruments too? I'll hear
No more I thank you, what have I done trow
To bring these fears about me? Son, where am I?

sp.speaker: Vvitty.
sp.l: Not where you should be, sir, you should be paying
For your music, and you are in a maze.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: O, is't so, put up, put up, I pray you,
Here's a crown for you.

sp.speaker: L. Ruin.
sp.l: Pish, a crown?

sp.speaker: Ru. Pris.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha, a crown?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Which way do you laugh? I have seen a crown
Has made a consort laugh heartily.

sp.speaker: Vvitty.
sp.l: Father,
To tell you truth, these are no ordinary
Musicians, they expect a bounty
Above their punctual desert.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: A — on your punks, and their deserts too.
Am I not cheated all this while think you?
Is not your pate in this?

sp.speaker: Vvitty.
sp.l: If you be cheated,
You are not to be indicted for your own goods,
Here you trifle time to market your bounty
And make it base, when it must needs be free
For ought I can perceive.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Will you know the lowest price, sir?

sp.speaker: Vvitty.
sp.l: That I will sir, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Unless I was discovered, and they now fled
Home again for fear, I am absolutely beguiled,
That's the best can be hoped for.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Faith 'tis somewhat too dear yet, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ruin.
sp.l: There's not a denier to be bated, sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Now sir, how dear is it?

sp.speaker: Vvitty.
sp.l: Bate but the tother ten pound?

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: Not a bawbee, sir.

sp.speaker: O. R.
sp.l: How? bate ten pound? what's the whole sum then?

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Faith sir, a hundred pound, with much ado ,
I got fifty bated, and faith father, to say truth,
'Tis reasonable for men of their fashion.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: La, la, la, down, a hundred pound? la, la, la,
You are a consort of thieves, are you not?

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: No musician's sir, I told you before.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Fiddle-faddle , is it not a robbery? A plain robbery?

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: No, no, no, by no means father, you have received
For your money, nay, and that you cannot give back,
'Tis somewhat dear I confess, but who can help it?
If they had been agreed with before hand,
'Twas ill forgotten.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: And how many shares have you in this? I see my force,
Case up your instruments, I yield, here, as robbed and
Taken from me, I deliver it.

sp.speaker: Vvitty.
sp.p: No sir, you have performed your promise now, which was, to pay the charge of music, that's all.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: I have heard no music, I have received none, sir, there's none to be found in me, nor about me.

sp.speaker: Vvitty.
sp.l: Why sir, here's witness against you, you have danced,
And he that dances acknowledges a receipt
Of music.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: I deny that sir, look you, I can dance without music, do you see sir? and I can sing without it too; you are a consort of thieves, do you hear what I do?

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Pray you take heed sir, if you do move the music again, it may cost you as much more.

sp.speaker: O.k.
sp.p: Hold, hold, I'll depart quietly, I need not bid you farewell, I think now, so long as that hundred pound lasts with you.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.l: Ha, ha, am I snapped i'faith?
O, sir, perfidious.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: Ay, ay, some howling another while, music's too damnable dear.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: O sir, my heartstrings are broke, if I can but live to tell you the tale I care not, your niece my charge is —

sp.speaker: O.k.
sp.p: What, is she sick?

sp.speaker: Gard,
sp.p: No, no sir, she's lustily well married.

sp.speaker: O.k.
sp.p: To whom?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: O, to that cunning dissembler, Cuningame.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: I'll hang the priest, first, what was he?

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: Your kinsman sir, that has the Welsh benefice.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: I saved him from the gallows to that end, good, is there any more?

sp.speaker: Garde
sp.p: And sir Gregory is married too.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: To my niece too, I hope, and then I may hang her.

sp.speaker: Gard.
sp.p: No sir, to my niece, thank Cupid; and that's all that's likely to recover me, she's lady fop now, and I am one of her ants I thank my promotion.

div.stage: Enter credulous, Cuningame, niece, sir Gregory, and Mirabell.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.p: I hate performed your behest sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: What have you performed sir?

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Faith sir, I must excuse my cousin in this act,
If you can excuse yourself for making him
A priest, there's the most difficult answer
I put this practice on him as from your desire,
A truth, a truth father.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.p: I protest sir, he tells you truth, he moved me to't in your name.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: I protest sir, he told you a lie in my name, and were you so easy Mr. credulous to believe him?

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.p: If a man should not believe his cousin sir, whom should he believe?

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: God-den to you good Mr. cousin Cuningame,
And your fair bride, my cousin Cuningame too,
And how do you, sir Gregory, with your fair lady?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: A little better than you would have had me, I thank you sir, the days of puppy, and slave, and rascal are pretty well blown over now, I know crabs from verjuice, I have tried both, and thou'dst give me thy niece for nothing I'd not have her.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I think so sir Gregory, for my sake you would not.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I would thou hadst scaped her too, and then she had died of the green sickness, know this, that I did marry in spite, and I will kiss my lady in spite, and love her in spite, and beget children of her in spite, and when I die they shall have my lands in spite; this was my resolution, and now 'tis out.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: How spiteful are you now, sir Gregory?
Why look you, I can love my dearest husband,
With all the honours, duties, sweet embraces,
That can be thrown upon a loving man.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: — This is afore your uncle's face, but behind his back in private you'll show him another tale.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: You see sir, now the irrecoverable state of all these things before you, come out of your muse, they have been but wit weapons, they were wont to love the play.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.p: Let me alone in my muse a little sir, I will wake to you anon.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Ued so, your friend Pompey, how will you answer him?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.p: Very well, if you'll but second it, and help me.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: I do hear strange storeys, are ladies things obnoxious?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.p: O, the dissembling falsest wretch is come.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: How now lady?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Let me come to him, and in stead of love
Let me have revenge.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Pray you now, will you first examine, whither he be guilty or no.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: He cannot be excused,
How many messengers (Thou perjured man)
Hast thou returned with vows and oaths? that thou
Wouldst follow, and never till this unhappy hour
Could I set eye of thee, since thy false dye
Drew my heart to it? o I could tear thee now,
In stead of soft embraces, pray give me leave —

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Faith this was ill done of you sir, if you promised otherwise.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: By this hand, never any messenger came at me since the first time I came into her company; that a man should be wronged thus?

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Did not I send thee scarves and diamonds?
And thou returned'st me letters, one with a false heart in't.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: On fie to receive favours, return falsehoods, and hold a lady in hand —

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Will you believe me sir? if ever I received diamonds, or scarf, or sent any letter to her, would this sword might never go through me.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Some bad messengers have gone between you then.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.p: Take him from my fight, if I shall see tomorrow .

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Pray you forbear the place, this discontent may impair her health much.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Foot, if a man had been in any fault 'twould never have grieved him, sir, if you'll believe.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Nay, nay, protest no more, I do believe you,
But you see how the lady is wronged by't;
She has cast away herself it is to be feared,
Against her uncle's will, nay, any consent,
But out of a mere neglect, and spite to herself,
Married suddenly without any advice.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Why who can help it? if she be cast away she may thank herself, she might have gone further and fared worse; I could do no more than I could do, 'twas her own pleasure to command me that I should not come till I was sent for, I had been with her every minute of an hour else.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Truly I believe you.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Night and day she might have commanded me, and that she knew well enough; I said as much to her between her and I, yet I protest she's as honest a lady for my part, that I'd say if she would see me hanged, if she be cast away I cannot help it, she might have stayed to have spoke with a man.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Well, 'twas a hard miss on both parts.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: So 'twas, I was within one of her, for all this cross luck, I was sure I was between the knight and home.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.p: Not gone yet? o my heart! none regard my health?

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: Good sir, forbear her sight a while, you hear how ill she brooks it.

sp.speaker: Clown
sp.p: Foolish woman, to overthrow her fortunes so; I shall think the worse of a lady's wit while I live for't — I could almost cry for anger, if she should miscarry now, 'twould touch my conscience a little, and who knows what love and conceit may do? what would people say as I go along? there goes he that the lady died for love on, lamb sure to hear on't ith' streets. I shall weep before hand; foolish woman, I do grieve more for thee now then I did love thee before; well, go thy ways, wouldst thou spare thy husband's head and break thine own heart? if thou hadst any wit, I would some other had been the cause of thy undoing, I shall be twitted i'th teeth with't, I'm sure of that, foolish lady. Exit.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.p: So, so, this trouble's well shaken off, uncle, how d'ye? there's a dowry due, sir.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.l: We have agreed it, sweetest,
And find your uncle fully recovered, kind to both of us.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p: To all the rest I hope;

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Never to thee, nor thee, easy cousin credulous,
Was your wit so raw?

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: Faith yours sir, so long seasoned
Has been faulty too, and very much to blame,
Speaking it with reverence, uncle.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: Yes faith, sir, you have paid as dear for your time as any man here.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.p:
I sir, and I'll reckon it to him. Imprimis, the first preface cheat of a pair of pieces to the beggars, you
remember that I was the example to your bounty there, I spoke greek, and Syriacke, sir, you understand me now. Next, the robbery put upon your indulgent cousin, which indeed was no robbery, no constable, no justice, no thief, but all cheaters; there was a hundred mark, mark you that. Lastly, this memorable 100. pounds worth of music, this was but cheats and wit too, and for the assistance, this gentleman to my cousin (For which I am to have a fee) that was a little practice of my wit too, father; will you come to composition yet, father?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Yes faith sir, do, two hundred a year will be easier than so much weekly, I do not think he's barren if he should be put to't again.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Why this was the day I looked for, thou shalt have't,
And the next cheat makes it up three hundred;
Live thou upon thy ten pound vicarage,
Thou gettest not a penny more, here's thy full
Hire now.

sp.speaker: Cred.
sp.l: I thank you sir.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Why there was the sum of all my wit father,
To shove him out of your favour, which I feared
Would have disinherited me.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Most certain it had,
Had not thy wit recovered it; is there any here
That had a hand with thee?

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Yes, all these sir.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Nephew, part a hundred pound amongst 'em,
I'll repay it; wealth, love me as I love wit;
When I die,
I'll build an almshouse for decayed wits.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.p: I'll entertain one in my life time; scholar, you shall be my chaplain, I have the gift of twenty benefices, simple as I am here.

sp.speaker: Pris.
sp.l: Thanks my great patron.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Sir, your gentry and your name shall both be raised as high as my fortunes can reach 'em, for your friend's sake.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Something will be in my present power, the future more,
You shall share with me.

sp.speaker: Ruin. and wife.
sp.l: Thanks worthy gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Niece.
sp.l: Sir, I would beg one thing of you?

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: You can beg nothing of me.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: O sir, if she begs, there's your power over her.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: She has begged me for a fool already, but 'tis no matter,
I have begged her for a lady that she might have been,
That's one for another.

sp.speaker: Witty.
sp.l: Nay, but if she beg —

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Let her beg again then.

sp.speaker: Niece
sp.p: That your man Pompey's coat may come over his ears back again, I would not he should be lost for my sake.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Well, 'tis granted, for mine own sake.

sp.speaker: Mirab.
sp.l: I'll entreat it sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Greg.
sp.l: Why then 'tis granted for your sake.

sp.speaker: O. K.
sp.l: Come, come, down with all weapons now, 'tis
Music time,
So it be purchased at an easy rate;
Some have received the knocks, some given the hits,
And all concludes in love, there's happy wits.Exeunt

div.head: The epilogue at the reviving of this play.
div.l: We need not tell you gallants, that this night
The wits have jumped, or that the scenes hit right,
'Twould be but labour lost for to excuse
What Fletcher had to do in, his brisk muse
Was so mercurial, that if he but writ
An act, or two, the whole play rise up wit.
We'll not appeal unto those gentlemen
Judge by their clothes, if they sit right, nor when
The ladies smile, and with their fans delight
To whisk a climb aside, than all goes right:
'Twas well received before, and we dare say,
You now are welcome to no vulgar play.
div.trailer: Here endeth wit at several weapons.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
